HEADLINE: In Cuomo's Last Administrative Job, a Program Was Tainted by Corruption

BYLINE: By RUSS BUETTNER and MIKE McINTIRE

 BODY:
It was a major embarrassment for Andrew M. Cuomo during his tenure as the nation's housing secretary.
 Inept and corrupt investors, some of them nonprofit organizations, bilked a loan program aimed at turning broken-down buildings into affordable housing, leaving taxpayers with a $250 million cleanup bill. Buildings were flipped, at fraudulently inflated prices, leading to hundreds of foreclosures. Parts of Harlem and Brooklyn were the hardest hit in the nation.
Mr. Cuomo, now the Democratic candidate for New York attorney general, has made his claim of having reduced waste and fraud at the Department of Housing of Urban Development a centerpiece of his campaign. He maintains that he quickly addressed the problems and that his tenure at the giant federal agency was marked by clean audits and improved balance sheets.
 ''Once HUD detected fraud in the program, it moved quickly to work with the F.B.I. and Department of Justice and prosecute the wrongdoers,'' said Wendy Katz, a Cuomo campaign spokeswoman. 
 A review of records, though, shows that Mr. Cuomo's top administrators had been warned for years about problems with the loan program. 
 The HUD inspector general issued warnings in 1996 that were echoed in an audit released and sent to Mr. Cuomo in February 1997, just after he took over the department. 
 Two years later, the General Accounting Office, the chief investigative arm of Congress, repeated the same warnings and criticized housing officials, saying they had not followed through on an agreement to fix the loan program. Even the private auditor that Mr. Cuomo's administration had hired said the risks of losses were so significant that HUD should revamp the program, or close it.
 Mr. Cuomo and his top managers have said they mistrusted reports by the inspector general because they believed she was politically motivated. They reacted to the General Accounting Office report, records show, by calling the program ''a minor, yet still important, portion'' of HUD's operation.
 Disputes aside, many people involved in the program agree that the department's delay in acting came with a huge cost: fraudulent schemes multiplied rapidly, especially in New York City. The federal government wound up covering $120 million in defaulted mortgages nationwide and an additional $130 million to repair the buildings in the city. The plans of neighborhood groups to provide more decent, affordable housing were set back years.
 Former City Councilman Bill Perkins, a Harlem Democrat who was one of the first to raise questions about abuses in New York, has called the schemes the ''worst scandal in the recorded history of our community.''
 Mr. Perkins, now a candidate for the State Senate, said Mr. Cuomo responded to appeals to resolve the problem before he left office in January 2001. But he added that Mr. Cuomo shared some of the blame for what occurred because ''it happened on his watch.''
 ''It was so deep and so insidious,'' he said. ''It made you wonder, 'How could this happen in the first place? Who was watching it?' ''
 Ms. Katz characterized the loan program, known as 203(K), as a tiny portion of the housing department's mission and its problems as an aberration. She said that during Mr. Cuomo's administration, the General Accounting Office lifted a ''high-risk'' designation from a major part of HUD's operation, a significant accomplishment for a troubled agency. She added that Mr. Cuomo's tenure had also reaped awards for innovation from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
 ''Focusing on the 203(K) program is an attempt to use the exception to try to disprove the rule,'' Ms. Katz said in an e-mail message. ''The clear 'rule' is that Cuomo did well at reforming a department that most believed was doomed.'' 
 Mr. Cuomo's job at HUD remains his only one managing a large government agency and is arguably the only position that approximates what will be his duties overseeing 500 lawyers, and more than 1,300 other employees, if he is elected attorney general on Tuesday.
 When he was nominated as HUD secretary by President Bill Clinton in December 1996, after four years as an assistant secretary, Mr. Cuomo inherited an agency with a $19 billion budget, more than 10,000 employees and a wounded reputation from years of scandals. His first order of business was to come up with an overhaul plan that would restore the department's credibility. 
 But as the Cuomo administration worked on the ambitious remaking of the agency, some of its officials were becoming increasingly aware of, and regulators were becoming alarmed by, abuses in the 203(K) program.
 The 203(K) program is HUD's main tool for rehabilitating single-family homes. Its loans differ from typical ones insured by its parent division, the Federal Housing Administration, in that the mortgage covers both the purchase price and the restoration costs. The program also allows investors and nonprofit groups to buy and improve the properties.
 In July 1996, an interim audit by the HUD inspector general found that appraisers, investors, lenders and lawyers were colluding to value unrepaired homes as if repairs had been made, then quickly sell them at artificially increased prices.
 ''The 203(K) program, as currently designed, is too risky because it permits investors, nonprofits and lenders to walk away with big profits, leaving HUD liable for the mortgages,'' the preliminary audit noted. 
 The program had been streamlined and marketed starting in 1994. Its insured loans soared to $3.6 billion in 1998 from $400 million in 1994, according to the General Accounting Office, whose name was changed in 2004 to the Government Accountability Office.
 In response to the 1996 audit, HUD banned profit-seeking investors. But many other suggestions would go unheeded for years. Due to staffing shortages, for example, the agency declined to add procedures to monitor loans to nonprofits, a later report noted.
 On Feb. 6, 1997, a week after Mr. Cuomo was confirmed by the Senate, the inspector general's final audit strengthened the preliminary findings. Among the flaws it found: Borrowers had never made the required down payments. Nonprofit groups were not performing the construction work within the six-month time limit, if at all, and had insufficient construction experience. Loans were granted on properties that did not need rehabilitation.
 William C. Apgar, who in 1998 took over the HUD division in charge of the program, the Federal Housing Administration, under Mr. Cuomo, said that some issues raised in the audits were addressed but that the situation also required changes to the law that established the 203(K) program. For instance, the law dictated that mortgage lenders, not HUD, chose appraisers to evaluate prospective properties, an arrangement that Mr. Apgar said made the program more susceptible to fraud.
 Mr. Apgar, who now teaches at Harvard, also said that Mr. Cuomo and others in HUD's leadership were deeply skeptical of Inspector General Susan Gaffney's work, saying it often seemed aimed at undermining the department's programs and ignored positive steps taken by its management. He suggested that politics was behind some of the criticism.
 ''There was definitely a partisan aspect to it,'' Mr. Apgar said. ''There were a lot of people back then gunning for Cuomo to knock him out of politics in New York.''
 Audits and Congressional testimony show that Ms. Gaffney, who was appointed by President Clinton to oversee 700 auditors and investigators at the HUD inspector general's office, had repeatedly criticized Mr. Cuomo's plan to revamp the agency as devoting too much staff to public relations functions and too little to oversight. 
 The relationship between Ms. Gaffney and Mr. Cuomo grew so tense that she ultimately filed a complaint accusing him and his aides of harassment, which she said included leaks of bogus and damaging information about her to reporters and abusive calls from Mr. Cuomo to her at home. At the time, a HUD spokeswoman dismissed the complaint as an attempt to divert attention from problems in Ms. Gaffney's own office. 
 Other reports, however, eventually buttressed Ms. Gaffney's warnings about the 203(K) program. 
 In October 1998, the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick, working under contract with Housing and Urban Development, issued a draft study that noted high default rates and that said HUD ''had done little to address the long-term viability of the program,'' according to the accounting office.
 Then, in June 1999, the accounting office released its report, substantiating the early warnings by the inspector general, and sent a copy to Mr. Cuomo. ''HUD management has done little to address problems with the program identified by both internal and external reviews over the past four years,'' it noted. 
 The accounting office said Mr. Apgar had not focused on the 203(K) program because he ''has been devoting most of his attention to addressing issues in programs that are much larger in scope and volume.''
 In its response, Mr. Apgar's office argued that the agency was doing enough: ''The department is pleased that the General Accounting Office (GAO) has taken the initiative to evaluate such a minor, yet still important, portion of F.H.A.'s overall business.''
 The audits had examined the program in 10 states, but not in New York. Abuse of the program in the city was quietly booming, however. 
 The first public hint of that came in a tenants' rights newsletter in April 1999, followed by an article that November in City Limits, a magazine about New York urban affairs. A wave of newspaper articles followed. 
 In January 2000, city newspapers noted that a Brooklyn-based nonprofit agency, Helpline Soul Rescue Ministry, had participated in the program, even though it had no previous experience in rehabilitation work. 
 Helpline was eventually accused of conspiring with real estate brokers and a lender to obtain inflated mortgages totaling $13.7 million on 65 buildings, according to a lawsuit filed by Attorney General Eliot Spitzer in 2000. The case was ultimately settled, with the defendants paying $257,000 to create a fund for tenants of the buildings. In all, nearly three dozen people were arrested, and at least 19 pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the scandal, most of them in New York.
 In early 2000, Mr. Cuomo began issuing regular press releases announcing that he was developing plans to curtail predatory lending. That spring he released plans to shore up the program against fraud, including seeking legislative changes. 
 ''Let's be clear: the 203(K) fraud in New York was the work of a criminal conspiracy of felons -- sellers, appraisers and some lenders,'' said Ms. Katz, the campaign spokeswoman. ''A dedicated conspiracy among multiple parties falsifying documents and determined to hide the facts takes time to untangle. The facts are those were criminal actions by criminals, who were caught by HUD, period.''
 But fixing the damage already wrought was an immediate concern in 2000. 
 Mr. Cuomo came to New York late that year to meet with leaders of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, the development arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, and other groups with experience in urban development issues. He asked for their help in working out a speedy solution, said Karen A. Phillips, who was then president of the corporation and now heads the Black Equity Alliance, a nonprofit group. 
 Mr. Cuomo's bailout plan was announced days before he left office in January 2001. He said it would be binding on the incoming administration. But the Bush administration did not agree and later negotiated its own a deal with the city to foreclose on and repair 500 buildings. That effort is nearly complete. 
 ''An effective plan was in place when Cuomo left,'' said Ms. Katz, his spokeswoman. ''The Bush administration then reversed that plan and created any lingering problems.''
 Irvin Henderson, the chairman of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, an organization that seeks to promote private investment in poor neighborhoods, credited Mr. Cuomo for his changes in 2000. But he said not enough was done before.
 ''When you look at Secretary Cuomo's role,'' Mr. Henderson said, ''I think much of the criticism speaks to the fact that there just was not the oversight necessary for all of the elements.''
 On Sept. 10, 2001, Congressional hearings were held on the scandal, but they were overshadowed by the terrorist attacks the next day. By then, Ms. Gaffney had retired. But even under new leadership, the inspector general's office did not spare HUD criticism over its performance on the 203(K) program.
 ''HUD's very poor management allowed this slow-moving theft of huge proportions to go undetected, until it was too late,'' Robert C. Groves, an assistant inspector general, said in testimony.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo, second from right, in 1999 with Vice President Al Gore and residents of Amsterdam, N.Y. Mr. Cuomo was in upstate New York to announce an economic revitalization grant. (Photo by Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: North Korea Talks: Back to the Table, Some Reluctantly

BYLINE: By HELENE COOPER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
Officially, the Bush administration is ''pleased'' -- as President Bush put it on Wednesday -- that North Korea has agreed to resume talks on nuclear disarmament. But behind closed doors at the White House and the State Department, some are less happy, saying the country's nuclear test should be answered with isolation.
 When it comes to North Korea, the Bush administration has always found itself pulled in two directions -- confrontation versus engagement -- and has generally settled on a middle course that was neither. To persuade North Korea to return to the bargaining table, President Bush agreed last week to a slight softening of his stance against direct talks with North Korea, a concession that made clear that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice was in charge of the policy, at least for now. 
But Ms. Rice is coming under increased fire inside and outside the administration from officials and experts who are skeptical about what diplomacy can achieve in this case, and who argue that there is no chance a new round of nuclear talks with North Korea will succeed.
 ''What's a good description? Fantasy? Dreamworld?'' said Nicholas Eberstadt, a North Korea expert with the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. ''All we're doing with these hapless efforts at conference diplomacy is continuing to talk while North Korea continues to build nuclear weapons.''
 A senior Bush administration official was equally pointed in criticizing the new initiative. ''In the past, the one thing we could never be criticized for was whether our tough talk meant something,'' said the official, who has participated in internal debates and would speak only on condition of anonymity about his dissenting views. ''When we gave a stick, they knew we were serious. We've lost that credibility.''
 This is not a new debate by any stretch. Within the administration, a more hawkish wing that includes Vice President Dick Cheney, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and John R. Bolton, the ambassador to the United Nations, has chafed against talks with any American foe, be it North Korea or Iran. Meanwhile, advocates of diplomacy, including R. Nicholas Burns and Philip D. Zelikow, two of Ms. Rice's top lieutenants at the State Department, have sided with European allies in saying that the United States should engage its foes.
 But the fact that the debate has resurfaced with such vigor suggests that even North Korea's decision to test a nuclear device on Oct. 9 in defiance of American warnings has not changed the old fault lines.
 Ms. Rice has found herself in the middle of the tug-of-war as she seeks to mute international criticism of America's so-called cowboy diplomacy. On the two big nuclear proliferation issues, Iran and North Korea, Ms. Rice has helped to move the administration away from unilateralism, with President Bush offering in May to join European negotiations over Iran's nuclear ambitions. 
 Even after North Korea conducted a round of missile tests in July and three months later tested the nuclear device, the United States continued to call for it to return to six-nation disarmament talks.
 ''Pretty clearly, the president of the United States thinks we're doing the right thing,'' the State Department spokesman, Sean McCormack, said Wednesday. ''This pathway is the best opportunity we have to achieve the objective we all share: a denuclearized Korean peninsula.''
 Ms. Rice argues that a new round of talks will be different and that the United States will wield more leverage because the negotiations will take place while North Korea is under United Nations sanctions for the nuclear test. But Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader, has participated in multiple rounds of talks over the past several years while accelerating his pursuit of nuclear weapons. 
 North Korea boycotted the talks last year after the United States imposed financial penalties in September 2005 on Banco Delta Asia, a bank in Macao, accusing it of helping the North launder money and pass counterfeit $100 bills manufactured by the North Korean government. 
 For a year, North Korea refused to return to the talks, and the United States refused to lift the sanctions. The Bush administration balked at North Korean overtures for one-on-one talks, insisting that America would talk to North Korea only as part of the six-party negotiations. But last week, Chinese officials contacted the American Embassy in Beijing and proposed a three-way meeting involving the United States, North Korea and China. That step required a shift in the American line against direct talks, but in response to a request from Ms. Rice, Mr. Bush agreed.
 The chief American negotiator, Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill, worked out the deal in a seven-hour session on Tuesday with his Chinese and North Korean counterparts. As a concession to entice North Korea back to the talks, the United States agreed to discuss the financial restrictions arising from the counterfeiting issue, a gesture that has been criticized inside and outside the administration.
 There is ''zero chance'' that the talks will persuade North Korea to dismantle its nuclear program, said John Tkacik, a senior research fellow at the Heritage Foundation and a former State Department diplomat. ''My Machiavellian mind tells me that the Chinese have worked out a deal with the Russians and the North Koreans that if North Korea comes back to the six-party talks, the main issue will not be denuclearization, it will be counterfeiting.''
 American negotiators continue to maintain the financial restrictions will remain unless North Korea stops counterfeiting United States currency. ''They have to get out of the illicit-activities business and get out of the counterfeiting business,'' Mr. Hill said in an interview Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Rife as Onion Domes, Moscow's Casinos Face Closing

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
Could there be a better symbol for the new Moscow -- seductive, indulgent, awash in got-quick riches -- than the casino?
 There are more than 60 of them in the city now, neon palaces of capitalist glitter and risk that have become as ubiquitous as the onion domes of Russian Orthodoxy. One major street, Novy Arbat, has more than a passing resemblance to the Las Vegas Strip, and even a casino called the Mirage.
 There is just one cloud on this rosy horizon: they are all to be closed, though perhaps not for a while.
 Pressed by President Vladimir V. Putin, the only political authority that matters anymore, lawmakers are drafting a law that would banish casinos, slot-machine parlors and other gambling halls from Moscow, though they could be allowed to operate in a few other places. 
 Unless lawmakers buck Mr. Putin, which has yet to happen, the new law would do more to alter the cityscape of Moscow than any other since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The Soviet government banned gambling -- even playing cards in public -- until the end of the 1980s and, perhaps not coincidentally, the end of its history.
 The first big casinos followed hard on the Soviet collapse, but they have proliferated since 2001, when an easing of licensing rules coincided with Russia's growing economic boom, creating a frenzy of easily disposed income. Industry officials here estimate that nearly $6 billion is spent on gambling each year in Russia.
 Moscow now has more casinos than any other city except Las Vegas and Miami, according to the World Casino Directory, an online industry association. (St. Petersburg is sixth.) That does not include hundreds of small shops with slot machines.
 ''The new Russians -- I would say 80 percent are gamblers,'' a gambler who declined to give more than his first name and patronymic, Vadim Pavlovich, said as he moved from the poker table to the roulette wheel at a casino here called Jazz Town. He estimates casually that he had lost a million dollars over time, money earned, he said vaguely, from wholesale trading. ''I have made enough to lose a million dollars,'' he said, fingering the chips in his hand.
 The gambling boom, perhaps inevitably, has generated a populist backlash that seems to have spurred Mr. Putin to act. While Russia hardly has a prudish society -- with its abundance of strip clubs, semilegal prostitution and a robust pornography industry -- opposition to gambling has become increasingly vocal.
 ''The gambling industry is highly unethical,'' said Aleksandr Y. Lebedev, a billionaire businessman and Parliament member who has long advocated a crackdown. ''It is legalized robbery.''
 Religious organizations, as well as the Public Chamber, a Kremlin-appointed advocacy council, publicly appealed this year for greater control, especially on slot machines. Two predominantly Muslim regions -- Chechnya and Dagestan -- have shut gambling parlors, while Tatarstan moved last month to restrict them to two special zones.
 On the national level, the lower house of Parliament has dickered for years over less sweeping changes to laws regulating gambling, voting already this year on a bill that would have distanced casinos and gambling halls from places like schools.
 Parliamentary leaders dropped that bill and put Mr. Putin's far stricter version on a fast track after he denounced gambling as a scourge in a public meeting with party leaders last month. A first vote on the legislation is scheduled for Nov. 17.
 ''Unfortunately, this concerns not just young people,'' Mr. Putin said last week about the effects of gambling on young people during a choreographed question-and-answer session with the public. ''Unfortunately, pensioners also leave their last kopecks and pensions there. Specialists say that this gambling addiction is even stronger than addiction to alcohol. This is a serious problem, and it has to be dealt with like the spread of alcohol in the country.''
 Mr. Putin's proposal appears to have popular support. In a recent poll of Russians by the independent polling agency Vtsiom, 65 percent of respondents favored restricting all gambling to special zones, while only 18 percent were opposed.
 The details of the law must still be put to paper, but Mr. Putin has said it would restrict all gambling to four specially designated zones -- evidently to be decided upon by his government later. The parliamentary speaker, Boris V. Gryzlov, emerged from the meeting with Mr. Putin last month vowing to allow casinos only in unpopulated areas. Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the nationalist party leader who was beside him, interjected, ''Virgin forests!''
 By all accounts, the legislation would banish gambling from Moscow and other major cities, though according to Itar-Tass, one version could create an exception for places more populated than the unspoiled forests mentioned by Mr. Zhirinovsky. Mr. Gryzlov said only that the zones would be spread across the country: one in the Far East, one in Siberia and two in European Russia.
 In a concession to existing casinos, the law would not take effect immediately but be phased in by 2009 -- time enough, supporters like Mr. Lebedev said, for owners to recoup their investments and close or relocate to the new zones.
 Already some cities or regions have lobbied for the designation and the tourism and tax revenue it could bring. They include Kaliningrad, the enclave between Poland and Lithuania, and Kalmykia, a Buddhist region on the northeast coast of the Caspian Sea governed by President Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, who has already built a Chess City that recently was host to the world championship.
 A small city on Moscow's southeastern outskirts, Ramenskoye, has also been cited as a potential location. A South African casino company, Sun International, has announced plans to build a large gambling and entertainment center there but said a final decision would depend on the legislation now being drafted.
 Michael Boettcher, a Briton who arrived in 1992, has built a chain of seven casinos, including some of Moscow's most prominent, including Jazz Town and another called Shangri La. He said that he welcomed restrictions because of the proliferation of casinos that did not follow industry standards, but that Mr. Putin's proposal went too far. ''Now, instead of coming with a reasonable approach,'' Mr. Boettcher said, ''they came with a club.''
 He, like others, said that gambling was too deeply rooted in Russian culture to be banished again, as it was during Soviet rule. In ''The Gambler,'' written to pay off gambling debt, Dostoyevsky suggested gambling was a compulsion somehow suited to the Russian soul. ''In my view all Russians are like that, or inclined to be,'' one character says, scolding the protagonist. ''If it's not roulette, it's something else like it.''
 Mikhail Chilkhodyants, who works in pharmaceuticals, prefers the slot machines. He meets friends at Jazz Town on occasion for an evening of entertainment. ''It's already become part of our lives,'' he said. ''Moscow without gambling will lose something.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: A doorman guarded a casino in central Moscow last month. Lawmakers are considering legislation that would ban casinos from the capital. (Photo by Justin Jin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Concentration of Competitive Races Puts Ohio at Center of Midterm Battle

BYLINE: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
Mary Jo Kilroy is an awkward, stumbling speaker. John Cranley is a baby-faced 32-year-old whose campaign biography still highlights his election as student body president in college. Dr. Victoria Wulsin has never held elected office. 
 But, reflecting the political drift of this bellwether state a week before the midterm elections, all three of these Democrats are in competitive races to unseat once-safe Republican members of Congress. With polls showing Democrats running well ahead in Ohio races for senator and governor, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has recently begun spending money to help Dr. Wulsin unseat her opponent, Representative Jean Schmidt, adding Ms. Schmidt to its list of three other Republican targets in the state.
Republicans, meanwhile, are scaling back their support for State Senator Joy Padgett in her fight against Zack Space, a Democrat who is the city attorney in Dover, for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Bob Ney, a Republican who pleaded guilty to corruption charges.
 That puts four Republican seats in play. Strategists for both sides say Mr. Ney's seat is the Democrats' best chance while Ms. Schmidt is the least vulnerable of the four Republicans. 
 Ohio has been a central battleground of the midterm elections because of the unusual concentration of competitive races. The Senate seat, now held by Senator Mike DeWine, is one of a half-dozen or so that will determine control of the chamber. The 4 House seats are among about 40 that will decide control of that body. And winning the governorship of Ohio can give a party a big assist in carrying the state in a presidential election.
 Discontent with the war in Iraq, the limping regional economy and a corruption scandal in the Republican-controlled statehouse tilted the table in favor of the Democrats from the start of the campaign. But in the final days before the election, Republicans are fighting hard to hold on.
 ''It's not over yet -- it's too early to wrap things up!'' Representative Deborah Pryce said in a telephone interview Monday on her way back from an event in Maryville.
 Ms. Pryce, the fourth-ranking member of the House Republican leadership and a moderate on many social issues, is facing her first competitive contest in a decade against Ms. Kilroy, a local county commissioner. Ms. Pryce is closing the race by reminding voters, in television commercials and campaign appearances, of the federally financed projects she has helped bring to the area. 
 ''We have to do something pro-active and not just bad-mouth and be negative,'' Ms. Pryce said in an interview Tuesday on a Columbus public radio station, WOSU. ''My solid record of bringing jobs to this community is exactly what we need to do.''
 Still, Ms. Pryce's anxiety is showing. In a reversal of the customary ritual between incumbent and challenger, Ms. Pryce recently stood with a bullhorn outside Ms. Kilroy's office demanding that Ms. Kilroy participate in another debate. Ms. Kilroy has refused. 
 ''She has come up with any excuse not to,'' Ms. Pryce said in the interview.
 ''Every time she says the president's name she says mine too,'' she added with frustration, saying she believed voters would see through the efforts to tie her to President Bush.
 Ms. Kilroy, in turn, is criticizing Ms. Pryce for describing the current national economy as ''storybook,'' arguing that she is out of touch with Ohio voters affected by the region's doldrums. 
 ''Two hundred and twenty thousand jobs were lost in a six-year period here in Ohio,'' Ms. Kilroy said Tuesday, also in an interview with WOSU. Like Republican candidates a decade ago, she called for reducing the federal deficit by requiring offsets for any new spending or tax cuts.
 In Cincinnati, Representative Steve Chabot is a staunch conservative first elected in the Republican landslide of 1994. Mr. Chabot's campaign is running commercials stating: ''Some people want you to think that I've changed. I've lived in the same house for 21 years, with my wife of 33 years. I still cut our grass, and drive the same old '93 Buick. More important, I've never wavered in our fight to cut spending, stand up to the special interests and protect Social Security.''
 The advertisement is a response to a refrain of his opponent, Mr. Cranley, that ''Washington changed Steve Chabot.'' Mr. Cranley, a city councilman, is running as a fiscal conservative, pledging not to accept a raise until the federal budget is balanced. Accusing Mr. Chabot of having abandoned his commitments to a balanced budget, Mr. Cranley recently won the endorsement of The Cincinnati Enquirer, which picked Republicans for most other races.
 Mr. Cranley is also attacking Mr. Chabot over his support for the Iraq war, reminding voters that Mr. Chabot recommended making Saddam Hussein ''a principal target'' shortly after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and that he once praised Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's job performance as ''exemplary.'' (Mr. Chabot says he, too, has some criticisms of the conduct of the war.)
 In the governor's race, polls show that Representative Ted Strickland, the Democratic candidate, has a commanding lead over J. Kenneth Blackwell, the Republican who is Ohio's secretary of state. Representative Sherrod Brown, the Democrat who is running for Senate, is also ahead of the Republican incumbent, Mr. DeWine, and the National Republican Senatorial Committee has stopped spending to support Mr. DeWine.
 The Democrats received an additional boost this week when the actor Michael J. Fox, who has Parkinson's disease, campaigned with Mr. Brown to highlight Mr. DeWine's opposition to embryonic stem cell research. Mr. Fox became famous playing the conservative son of liberal parents in a television show set in Columbus, and his appearance dominated television news coverage around the state that day.

MS. KILROY

HEADLINE: Bush Works to Solidify Base With a Defense of Rumsfeld

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
With less than a week before the election, President Bush sought to rally Republican voters on Wednesday with a vigorous defense of the war in Iraq and a vow to keep Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld in office until the end of Mr. Bush's term.
 Mr. Bush appeared on Rush Limbaugh's radio program, whose audience is a reservoir of conservative voters, to criticize Democrats as lacking a plan for victory in Iraq. 
 Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney also spent another day going after Senator John Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee two years ago, for remarks that Republicans say insulted the intelligence of American troops in Iraq.
 ''Anybody who is in a position to serve this country ought to understand the consequences of words,'' Mr. Bush said, ''and our troops deserve the full support of people in government.''
 Mr. Kerry said in a statement issued on Wednesday by his office that his ''poorly stated joke at a rally was not about and never intended to refer to any troop.'' 
 As Mr. Bush worked to solidify his base, Democratic and Republican Party committees were making some of their final moves on the electoral chessboard. The Republican Senate committee reported spending nearly $1 million on television advertisements in Maryland and more than $800,000 in Michigan. The Senate seats in those states are held by Democrats and have generally been considered safe, but the investments by Republicans suggested a hope of making them competitive.
 Democrats sought to expand the contest for the Senate as well by buying air time in Arizona to rattle, if not defeat, Senator Jon Kyl, a Republican thought to be headed for relatively easy re-election. Democratic officials would not disclose how much they were spending.
 Mr. Bush, in an interview with wire service reporters on Wednesday, said he intended to keep Mr. Rumsfeld at the Pentagon and Mr. Cheney in the vice presidency until he leaves office in 2009. Both are controversial figures, even among some Republicans, but they are also popular with conservatives who form the foundation of Mr. Bush's political and electoral strategy.
 With polls showing a majority of Americans unhappy with the course of the war and many Republican candidates distancing themselves from Mr. Bush on it, the White House was taking a gamble on making Iraq the central subject of discussion in the final week of the campaign. His embrace of Mr. Rumsfeld carried particular risk, since some Republican candidates have joined nearly all Democrats in seeking his dismissal.
 Democrats responded to the Republicans' efforts with new advertisements accusing Mr. Bush and Mr. Rumsfeld of botching the war and making the United States less safe. A television spot from the Democratic Congressional committee said, ''The White House is in denial as top generals warn that Iraq may be sliding into full-scale civil war.''
 A veterans group released an advertisement on Wednesday in which Iraq war veterans and Gen. Wesley K. Clark, who is retired and who was a Democratic presidential candidate in 2004, criticize the war. ''Because of Iraq, there are more terrorists in the world,'' one veteran says. 
 Democrats also criticized Representative John A. Boehner, the No. 2 Republican in the House, as seeming to shift responsibility for problems in Iraq from Secretary Rumsfeld to the uniformed military.
 ''Let's not blame what's happening in Iraq on Rumsfeld,'' Mr. Boehner said in an interview on CNN on Wednesday afternoon. ''But the fact is, the generals on the ground are in charge, and he works closely with them and the president.''
 Seeking to a draw a parallel to the flap over Mr. Kerry's comments, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, demanded that Mr. Boehner apologize to the generals.
 ''John Boehner ought to be ashamed,'' Mr. Reid said in a statement. ''He's blaming our troops for failures in Iraq.'' 
 Republican leaders hoped to buck up morale among conservative Christians, a normally reliable source of Republican votes. A sizeable number of such so-called values voters have told pollsters that they are unhappy with Mr. Bush and the Republican-led Congress and might stay home on Election Day or vote for Democrats.
 James C. Dobson, founder of Focus on the Family and an influential voice among evangelical Christian voters, said on his radio program this week that Democrats and the news media were trying to suppress the conservative vote by reporting on unhappiness among evangelicals.
 Mr. Dobson also warned that a Democratic takeover of Congress would bring ''crippling setbacks in the battles against abortion and gay marriage.'' 
 In recent days, Mr. Bush and his surrogates have sought to rally Republicans by raising the specter of what they call unreconstructed liberal Democrats leading powerful committees if the Democrats regain control of Congress. Mr. Cheney took aim at one of them, Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, who is in line to become chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which writes tax laws.
 Mr. Cheney said late last week that Mr. Rangel knew nothing about the American economy and would raise taxes as soon as he took over the committee.
 Mr. Rangel responded by using a profanity to question Mr. Cheney's parentage. He said in an interview Wednesday that he was sorry for his choice of words, but not for the thought. He said he hoped that if the Democrats won control of Congress the nasty language on both sides would cease.
 ''I can take a political shot,'' Mr. Rangel said. ''But my family and friends and constituents deserve better from the vice president of the United States.''

HEADLINE: In the Race For Governor, A Big Divide On School Aid

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

 BODY:
As attorney general, Eliot Spitzer has performed a legal high-wire act on education aid.
 He dutifully fought a lawsuit seeking billions of dollars more for the New York City schools, while insisting that he personally disagreed with the position he had to take as the state's top lawyer. Now, Mr. Spitzer promises that if he is elected governor, he will resolve the case by providing a total of up to $8.5 billion more a year for the city and for other needy school districts statewide.
Mr. Spitzer's willingness to allocate vastly more education aid to the city sets him apart not only from his Republican opponent, John Faso, but also from Gov. George E. Pataki and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who, despite their party and policy differences, both fought the suit, now 13 years old. 
 ''This is something that has to be solved not just because it's a litigation but because it's the right thing to do,'' Mr. Spitzer said recently. Mr. Faso counters that the state already pays enough for schools -- $32 billion a year -- and does not get sufficient value. 
 Perhaps no issue in the governor's race holds greater import for the near-term future of New York than education. Lower courts have ordered at least $4.7 billion a year more for New York City's schools, and a final ruling from the state's highest court is expected in December. 
 That will set the stage for a showdown on school aid, an issue that turns every lawmaker into a pit bull intent on taking home the biggest bone and raises hard questions about what the state can afford. 
 Mr. Spitzer, a Democrat, says the state could afford to keep his promise by closing hospitals and slashing Medicaid costs. Mr. Faso insists that the increased education costs would be so great that Mr. Spitzer would have to raise taxes. 
 Mr. Faso, a former Assembly minority leader steeped in the intricacies of education aid, agrees with Mr. Spitzer that the financing system needs an overhaul so that districts with the greatest needs get priority. But he insisted, in an interview, that increases in spending would be a mistake. 
 ''We have to examine how we are spending the $32 billion, K through 12, that we are now expending,'' he said. ''I don't subscribe to the notion that simply putting more into the existing system is wise or necessary.'' He added, ''As I travel around the state -- you know there are over 700 school districts; 650 of them think they are not getting enough from the state.'' 
 The budget question is only the start of the policy challenges facing the state on education: New York's high school graduation rate ranks about 40th in the nation and near last for minority students. Just under half of New York's eighth graders read proficiently and in poor, urban areas the number is even lower. Many policy makers say the state's economic prospects hinge on improving schools. 
 ''For New York State to succeed and become vibrant again, education and economic development have to become top priorities,'' said Abraham M. Lackman, who has been both a top budget aide to the Republican-controlled State Senate and a New York City budget director. 
 ''The next governor has got to spend money on education, and he has got to make sure it gets results,'' added Mr. Lackman, president of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, a private policy group based in Albany.
 Neither candidate came up through the public school system. Mr. Spitzer attended Horace Mann, the prep school in Riverdale, and Princeton University.
 Mr. Faso, whose father worked as a janitor in the Catholic grammar school that he attended on Long Island, went on to Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens and the State University of New York at Brockport. 
 Still, despite their disparate backgrounds, the candidates have some surprising agreements, with Mr. Spitzer more enthusiastic than many other Democrats on providing alternatives to traditional public schools. 
 Mr. Spitzer and Mr. Faso alike say they would fight to lift a state cap that has limited the number of charter schools to 100 statewide. An effort to do that was blocked last session by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver. 
 At the same time, the two candidates say they would provide some relief to school districts like Albany and Buffalo, where officials say the publicly financed but privately managed charters are a fiscal drain on the regular schools. And both candidates favor expanded tax credits to help parents afford private schools or tutoring.
 When it comes to New York City, both candidates support reauthorizing mayoral control of the school system, which will expire in 2009. And both favor merit bonuses and salary differentials for teachers in hard-to-staff schools and in areas with a shortage of teachers, like math, science and special education. 
 Yet Mr. Faso says that the SUNY system from which he graduated is doing well, while Mr. Spitzer says that SUNY lacks the prestige of systems like those in California and Michigan. ''Our public higher educational system should be on par with the finest in the nation,'' he said in an interview, a competitive glint in his eye. ''I don't think it is right now.'' 
 Still, higher education issues are almost certain to be overshadowed by the battle over school financing. 
 Mr. Faso says officials should await the final ruling from the Court of Appeals. He noted that it could substantially reduce the amount ordered to New York City by the lower courts because of increases in state aid in recent years, including $11.2 billion in financing for school construction authorized this year. 
 Taking direct aim at the state's powerful teachers unions, Mr. Faso also has very specific goals to reduce costs to local school districts. He would seek to eliminate laws that he says make it difficult to renegotiate labor contracts and virtually impossible to fire tenured educators. He would also like to allow school districts to offer 401(k) retirement plans instead of pension packages. 
 Mr. Spitzer, on the other hand, has the unions' support and recently toured a charter school in Brooklyn run by the city union, the United Federation of Teachers. The union president, Randi Weingarten, boasted of creating a model school with no more than 25 students per class and two teachers in each room. 
 She said she believed her members would be better off with Mr. Spitzer: ''We put our money where our mouth is, and I believe the man standing to my right is going to do exactly the same thing when he is elected governor.'' 
 Mr. Spitzer, who has consistently led by wide margins in the polls, has not been as specific about many of his education proposals. His opponent in the Democratic primary chided him for not releasing a detailed education plan -- and he has yet to do so. But he says that additional spending is needed for things like smaller classes, longer school days and years, wider availability of pre-kindergarten and improved teacher training. 
 In one case, discussing details got him into trouble. He recently infuriated Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg by telling the Daily News editorial board that New York City should pay a share of any court-ordered increase in aid for the city's schools. 
 The mayor fired back, saying the city would not pay a dime. And Mr. Faso also pounced, asserting that Mr. Spitzer had suggested that the reauthorization of mayoral control could be part of the negotiations over financing. He accused Mr. Spitzer of planning ''to resort to the normal barter and trade mechanisms of Albany'' by holding mayoral control ''hostage.'' 
 Mr. Spitzer quickly tamped down the spat, saying that he had not pegged a specific amount for the city's share and that the issue was subject to negotiation. 
 Policy advisers to Mr. Spitzer say he now hopes to give a major education address in mid-November -- as the governor-elect.

HEADLINE: Worries About Earnings Depress Shares

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday for the first time this week after a slowdown in manufacturing added to concern that earnings forecasts were too high.
 United Technologies, the maker of Pratt & Whitney jet engines, led a decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Nasdaq composite index had its biggest loss in eight weeks after sales at Garmin, the maker of portable navigation devices, trailed analysts' estimates and its shares tumbled.
The drop in the factory index of the Institute for Supply Management ''raises a real question about how serious the slowdown is going to be,'' said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company in New York, which manages about $10 billion. ''It brings into question earnings,'' and that can be ''lethal'' for stocks, he said. 
 The Dow industrials fell 49.71 points, or 0.4 percent, to 12,031.02. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 10.13 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,367.81. The Nasdaq declined 32.36 points, or 1.4 percent, to 2,334.35.
 Drug retailers slumped on speculation that they would have to make acquisitions after the CVS chain agreed to buy Caremark Rx for about $21 billion. Drug-benefit managers dropped, led by Express Scripts, after the offer for Caremark fell short of the stock's market price.
 Stocks retreated after the drop in the factory index for October wiped out initial gains, tied to higher-than-expected earnings from companies like MasterCard and Cigna.
 The factory gauge fell to 51.2 from 52.9 last month. Economists had expected 53, a Bloomberg survey showed. Readings above 50 signal expansion. A report on Tuesday showed that consumer confidence dropped unexpectedly, and the government said a day earlier that household spending rose less than forecast.
 United Technologies declined $1.47, or 2.2 percent, to $64.25, the biggest drop in the Dow average. Alcoa, the aluminum maker, lost 43 cents, to $28.33, adjusted for a dividend payout.
 Among drugstore chains, CVS dropped $2.32, or 7.4 percent, to $29.06 for the second-biggest slide in the S.& P. 500. Its takeover of Caremark ignited speculation that rival drugstore chains would be forced to pursue deals of their own to compete.
 Walgreen, CVS's larger competitor, slid $1.57, to $42.11, while Rite Aid slid 16 cents, to $4.52.
 Caremark slumped $1.06, or 2.2 percent, to $48.17, after accepting CVS's offer of $48.76 a share, which was 1 percent less than its own closing price Tuesday. Medco Health Solutions, its biggest competitor, fell $2.83, to $50.67. Express Scripts slid $3.73, to $59.99.
 Garmin sank $8.43, or 16 percent, to $44.98, the biggest decline in more than two years. Garmin's sales increased 62 percent last quarter to $408 million. Analysts on average had estimated $423.4 million, according to Thomson Financial. Sales in the auto unit missed projections.
 Shares of MasterCard and Cigna advanced after their quarterly earnings exceeded analysts' estimates. 
 MasterCard jumped $10.97, or 15 percent, to $85.07, the biggest gain since it went public in May. It said third-quarter profit surged 82 percent because its cardholders spent more and new pricing for overseas purchases bolstered revenue.
 Cigna rose $1.99, to $118.97, after reporting that net income rose 15 percent as membership grew. The company also said full-year income from operations would be $8.85 to $9.15 a share, up from its August forecast of $8.30 to $8.80.
 Bonds were up, with the price of the benchmark 10-year note rising 9/32, to 102 14/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, was 4.56 percent, down from 4.60 percent.

HEADLINE: October Sales Were Weak At Wal-Mart

BYLINE: By JEREMY W. PETERS

 BODY:
Where are Americans spending all the money they're saving on gas? Not at Wal-Mart, it seems.
 Wal-Mart Stores was one of several large retailers, along with Target and Costco, to post disappointing October sales totals yesterday. The results suggest that lower- and middle-class Americans are holding on tightly to their wallets even as energy prices fall and wages rise.
 With the holiday shopping season approaching, the consumer's reluctance to spend raises questions about how robust holiday sales will be.
 As Wal-Mart reported a meager 0.5 percent rise last month in same-store sales -- those at stores open at least a year -- the company, the world's largest retailer, also warned that November was probably going to be even worse. In a statement, it said sales this month were ''estimated to be approximately flat.'' That would be the company's worst performance in more than 10 years. 
 In response, Wal-Mart is expected to make sharp price cuts weeks before the traditional start of the holiday shopping season, the Friday after Thanksgiving. The company, which has already cut the prices of 100 popular toys, is expected to focus its next round of price cuts on electronics.
 The unimpressive retail results helped deflate stock prices on Wall Street yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, in which Wal-Mart is a large component, closed lower for the fifth straight day. Wal-Mart shares fell 56 cents, or 1.2 percent, to close at $48.29. The drop accounted for about a third of the Dow's 12-point loss yesterday.
 Stocks also fell yesterday as the Labor Department reported that worker productivity did not improve in the third quarter as wages rose and a measure of inflation ticked higher.
 Target and Costco also reported October sales yesterday that fell short of Wall Street's expectations. While both reported gains from a year earlier -- 3.9 percent and 4 percent, respectively -- they were outperformed by many major department stores, which have recently been among the strongest performers in the retail industry. 
 Federated Department Stores, owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, said its same-store sales jumped 7.7 percent. J. C. Penney reported an 8.1 percent sales gain. Nordstrom, the high-end department store based in Seattle, said sales grew 10.7 percent. 
 The slowdown in business at big-box retailers like Wal-Mart is one sign that some consumers are cutting back as the weakening housing market is dragging down overall economic growth.
 But even as the economy continues to downshift, wages are increasing and Americans are finding themselves with more disposable income, in part because of falling gas prices. Instead of spending that money, low-and middle-income consumers appear to be sticking to their budgets.
 ''Energy prices have come down, so wouldn't that give a lift to the lower-income consumer who has been most hurt by the rise?'' said Michael P. Niemira, chief economist of the International Council of Shopping Centers. ''It's a little bit of a question mark.'' 
 Mr. Niemira said one possible explanation was that lower-income Americans were spending that extra cash at department stores. ''Is that consumer shopping elsewhere? Are they now moving to Penny's and Kohl's, which are having booming sales?'' 
 There is some evidence to suggest that Americans are putting more money aside. This week, the Commerce Department reported that the national personal savings rate in September came the closest it has in a year and a half to being positive. It was negative $15 billion, its healthiest level since May 2005.
 Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at the investment firm ITG, said that the reaction of consumers to falling gas prices had been a mirror image of what they did when prices soared: by and large, they did not alter their spending habits. ''They ignored it on the way up, and they're ignoring it on the way down.''
 Recent surveys have given a split picture on consumer confidence. Last week, the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment hit the highest level since July 2005. But numbers released by the Conference Board this week showed that consumer confidence waned in October.
 ''Consumers aren't expecting the economy to take off, nor are they expecting it to head into a recession,'' said Lynn Franco, director of the consumer research center at the Conference Board. 
 Ms. Franco said that consumer spending was not likely to show big gains in the next few months. She forecast growth through the rest of the year as ''basically more or less the same.''
 For the holiday shopping season, that could spell trouble for retailers. But the always-resilient American consumer is a hard animal to predict.
 ''Betting against Christmas is a loser,'' Mr. Barbera said. 
 Despite the restrained consumer spending and conflicting signals on consumer confidence, wages have risen. The Labor Department reported yesterday that the average hourly wages of American workers rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.7 percent in the third quarter. But productivity was surprisingly unchanged; economists had expected about a 1 percent gain.
 Economists said that two forces appeared to be at work: a slowing economy that was dragging output down and a tight labor market that was driving costs up.
 ''Slowing growth leads to falling productivity, and that is exactly what is now happening,'' Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors, said in a research note. ''Even though labor compensation increased less rapidly, it was still fast enough to continue the ominous surge in unit labor costs that began last year.''
 Though rising labor costs mean that American workers are earning more, higher wages can also lead to higher prices for goods and services. And the Federal Reserve is closely watching data on inflation as it decides whether to resume raising interest rates, keep them steady or start cutting them to stimulate the economy. 
 The Labor Department report showed that higher pay and flat productivity combined to produce a higher jump than expected in one measure of inflation, unit labor costs, which rose 3.8 percent in the third quarter, at an annual rate.
 The broader slowing of the economy also manifested itself in new statistics on manufacturing released yesterday by the Commerce Department. Factory orders rose 2.1 percent in September, less than expected, and nearly all of the increase was accounted for by a cluster of orders for large aircraft.

 Analysts said the poor sales raised questions about how robust the holiday shopping season would be. (Photo by Paul Sancya/Associated Press)(pg. C4)
