HEADLINE: Democrats Oust G.O.P. In Governing Six States

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Democrats won open governor's seats in five states Tuesday and knocked off the Republican incumbent in Maryland, tilting control of the majority of governorships to Democrats for the first time since the 1990s.
 The Republicans began Election Day with a 28 to 22 advantage over the Democrats in governorships.
 But they were faced with the daunting prospect of defending nine of the ten open seats amid a mood that was decidedly anti-Republican in many parts of the country. Democrats were able to capture statehouses in the Northeast, the West and the South. The open seats were in Arkansas, Colorado, Massachusetts, New York and Ohio.
 In Florida, Republicans were able to protect the seat that Gov. Jeb Bush has controlled for two terms. But in Maryland, Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore, a Democrat, edged Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. 
 In dozens of other races, incumbents in states like Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Texas carried the day, despite some solid challenges.
 Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California handily defeated his Democratic rival, delivering a high-profile Republican victory in a state where not a single Republican held high state office just four years ago. His re-election highlighted a night of victories by incumbents. 
 But it was the races for the open seats -- 10 in all, out of a total of 36 contests -- that held much of the political attention.
 In Ohio, Ted Strickland, 65, a five-term congressman, defeated J. Kenneth Blackwell, a Republican and the secretary of the state. 
 Ohio Republicans were under a cloud because the current governor, Bob Taft, a Republican, pleaded no contest last year to ethics charges arising from dealings with a crooked investment manage. Until Tuesday, Republicans had dominated Ohio state politics, including the governor's office for the last 16 years.
 In Massachusetts, voters elected Deval Patrick, a civil rights lawyer and former Clinton administration official. Mr. Patrick, 50, defeated Kerry Healey, the Republican lieutenant governor. He is the first African-American elected as governor in Massachusetts and will become only the second elected black governor in the nation's history since Reconstruction. The current governor, Mitt Romney, a Republican, chose not to run again.
 In New York, the state's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, easily defeated John J. Faso, a Republican, to capture the seat now held by George E. Pataki, the nation's longest-serving governor. Mr. Pataki, a Republican who came to office in 1994 with an upset victory over the Democrat Mario M. Cuomo, did not seek re-election.
 The Democrats picked up a fourth open seat in Arkansas, where the attorney general, Mike Beebe, defeated Asa Hutchinson, a former official in the federal Department of Homeland Security.
 President Bush and other officials in his administration had made repeated visits to Arkansas on behalf of Mr. Hutchinson in recent weeks. Political analysts said before the election that conservative voters in the state had been dispirited by the war and the sex scandal in Congress involving under-age pages. Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican was barred by term limits from running again. 
 In Colorado, Bill Ritter, a Democrat and former district attorney in Denver, defeated two-term Representative Bob Beauprez, a Republican, in the race to succeed Gov. Bill Owens.
 It was a night that saw incumbent after incumbent raise hands in victory.
 Mr. Schwarzenegger's victory was particularly remarkable given that the governor, who won his seat in a 2004 recall of the Democratic governor, appeared to be all but finished just six month ago after a series of ballot initiatives he presented to voters failed.
 Mr. Schwarzenegger outspent his opponent, Phil Angelides, the state treasurer, and outdanced him to the left during the campaign. He passed a minimum-wage increase, a bill to curb heat-trapping gases at the potential expense of large companies, a measure approving prescription-drug discounts, all the while supporting stem cell research and openly criticizing the White House on issues like its order to police the Mexican border with National Guard troops
 In Connecticut, Gov. M. Jodi Rell, a Republican, defeated John DeStefano, the mayor of New Haven and a Democrat. Gov. Sonny Perdue, Republican of Georgia, and Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina, also a Republican, were both re-elected. 
 Republicans also held onto the governor's seat in Florida that many Democrats had desperately coveted -- if only for the psychological impact on the Bush administration, since it was being vacated by Jeb Bush, President Bush's brother, who could not run again because of term limits. Charlie Crist, the Florida attorney general, beat Representative Jim Davis in that race.
 In New Hampshire, Gov. John Lynch, a Democrat, was re-elected over his Republican challenger, Jim Coburn. And Edward G. Rendell, the Democratic incumbent in Pennsylvania, held on to win re-election against his Republican challenger, Lynn Swann, the former professional football player who is now a sports commentator. 
 The Democratic incumbent in Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich, also turned back a Republican challenge, from Judy Baar Topinka. Gov. Phil Bredesen of Tennessee, a Democrat, also won re-election, easily defeating his Republican challenger, Jim Bryson.
 But some incumbent victories came after a fierce political fight, especially in Michigan, where Jennifer M. Granholm, a Democrat, held off her challenger, Dick DeVos, to win re-election. Ms. Granholm won despite the unhappiness of voters who had seemed ready, earlier in the campaign season, to blame her for the state's bad economy and lost auto industry jobs.
 In the Rocky Mountain West, where Democrats have made big gains in governors' seats and in state legislatures in recent years, Democratic incumbents won all their races. Gov. Janet Napolitano of Arizona won re-election, as did Gov. Dave Freudenthal in Wyoming and Gov. Bill Richardson in New Mexico.
 As voters cast their ballots across the country Tuesday, the big question in many state capitals was how much national politics they would effect their choices. 
 .
 In Rhode Island, one of the most solidly Democratic states in national elections, Gov. Donald L. Carcieri, a Republican, scrambled to remind voters why they had elected him four years ago. 
 But in the end, the real key to the governors' elections, many party leaders and political scholars said, centered on one big factor: the number of open seats.
 Six incumbents, including Governor Bush of Florida, were barred by term limits from seeking re-election, and four governors -- James E. Risch of Idaho, Tom Vilsack of Iowa, Mr. Romney of Massachusetts and Mr. Pataki of New York -- chose not to run again. In the 10 governors' races without an incumbent, nine of the governors who were stepping aside were Republicans.
 Mr. Patrick's victory in Massachusetts will make him the nation's only sitting black governor. L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat from Virginia, was the nation's first elected black governor since Reconstruction, serving from 1990 to 1994.
 Mr. Patrick served as a lawyer for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund in the early 1980s, working mostly on death penalty and voting rights cases. He met Bill Clinton, then the governor of Arkansas, when he sued him in a voting case. In 1994, when he was president, Mr. Clinton appointed Mr. Patrick assistant attorney general for civil rights, the nation's top civil rights post.

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: THE HOUSE; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: On Wave of Voter Unrest, Democrats Take Control of House

BYLINE: By CARL HULSE

 BODY:
Democrats rode voter unrest over Congressional misconduct and the war in Iraq back to power in the House on Tuesday night, ending 12 years of Republican rule by persuading voters it was time to change course in Washington.
 Led by a string of victories in the Northeast and Midwest, Democrats gained at least 21 seats, 6 more than the 15 required to install Representative Nancy Pelosi of California as the first woman to become speaker of the House. Assuming they hold on to enough of their incumbent seats elsewhere, Democrats will hold the House majority for the first time since 1994.
''Today, the American people have stated loud and clear that they want a new direction for our country,'' said an ebullient Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, who is in line to become the chairwoman of the House Rules Committee in the new Democratic regime. 
 Republicans were dogged by scandal throughout the campaign, and it cost them dearly. They lost seats in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and Florida as the direct result of criminal cases and other misconduct. Exit polls showed that corruption weighed heavily on the minds of voters. 
 But public dissatisfaction with the Iraq war and other issues was clear. Three Republican incumbents were defeated in conservative Indiana and another in Kentucky. Two moderate Republicans were ousted in New Hampshire and at least one more in Connecticut. New York, with Democrats leading the top of the ticket, gave the party at least two more seats. Democratic gains mounted as votes were counted in the West.
 The White House acknowledged that the once overwhelming Republican majority in the House had slipped away. 
 ''We believe Democrats will have control of the House and look forward to working with Democratic leaders on the issues that remain foremost on the agenda, including winning the war in Iraq and the broader war on terror and keeping the economy on a growth path,'' said Tony Snow, the White House spokesman.
 Ms. Pelosi told an enthusiastic crowd in Washington that her resurgent majority was prepared to work with Republicans ''in partnership and not in partisanship,'' hoping to break the gridlock of what could be a divided Congress.
 ''The campaign is over -- Democrats are ready to lead,'' she said. ''Today we have made history -- now let us make progress.''
 Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, who was expected to retire should Republicans slip into the minority, was not ready to concede, though he said, ''We've watched some of the House races, especially in the East -- been kind of tough out there.''
 The Republican setback will likely spur leadership fights beginning Wednesday as ambitious lawmakers in both parties try to find their way in the reshaped House. 
 Democratic control of the House will begin a new era in Washington, giving the party the votes to install its members as committee leaders and initiate more aggressive oversight of the Bush administration. Democrats have complained for years that Republicans have ignored their responsibility as an independent branch of government to police the executive branch.
 The party has also promised a legislative agenda that starts with an increase in the minimum wage and giving the government the power to negotiate for lower drug prices for Medicare. But with control of the Senate uncertain and the margin so close, it is unlikely the new Democratic majority will have a free hand.
 In Indiana, three Republican incumbents who were top targets of the Democrats -- John Hostettler, Chris Chocola, and Mike Sodrel -- lost.
 In Connecticut, Chris Murphy, a Democrat, was declared the winner in a race against Representative Nancy Johnson, a moderate Republican.
 And in Kentucky, another Republican Representative, Anne M. Northup, a veteran lawmaker who had withstood strong challenges in the past, lost narrowly to her Democratic opponent, John Yarmuth, a former Republican political candidate and publisher of an alternative newspaper in Louisville. Democrats had not counted on beating Ms. Northup in making their calculation for a House takeover.
 In Georgia, in fact, two Democratic incumbents, John Barrow and Jim Marshall, were in tight races of their own, though they were among only a few party lawmakers who were considered in danger of defeat. 
 Republicans had known for months that they faced a volatile political environment, but they believed they could stem serious losses because many of the lawmakers most in jeopardy were in Republican-friendly districts and the party had the benefit of a powerful turnout operation.
 They were also counting on the fact that House races traditionally turn on local issues rather than the national political picture. But a national exit poll indicated that most voters in House races were viewing this crucial midterm through the prism of national concerns. In another sign of struggle for the Republicans, voters also rated corruption as one of their major considerations. 
 The seeds for the Republicans' precarious position in the House were planted in the early days of the 109th Congress in January 2005, when House leaders found themselves in a clash with Democrats over charges of corruption and their iron-fisted management of the chamber. Over the next two years, the Republicans were plagued by a series of lobbying and personal scandals, internal disputes over spending, and an uncertain new leadership.
 At the pinnacle of the chamber's turmoil was Tom DeLay, the former Republican leader and key architect of the party's control over the House, who was indicted in Texas on a campaign finance law charge and faced an ethics inquiry in Congress. Angry over a series of rebukes by the ethics committee to Mr. DeLay, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert forced through a series of changes that Democrats and watchdogs saw as a campaign to weaken internal policing. Democrats balked, setting the angry and combative tone for the session.
 At the same time, the influence-peddling scandal tied to the lobbyist Jack Abramoff continued to simmer and other scandals, notably a bribery case that led to the conviction of former Representative Randy Cunningham, Republican of California, provided substance for the Democratic charge that the Republican-led House had lost its ethical bearings.
 As they left for the campaign trail at the end of September, Republicans found themselves where they began, contending with the toxic fall-out of former Representative Mark Foley sexually suggestive messages to male teenage pages, throwing the party badly off message and providing a last straw for voters already upset with the majority.

SECTION: Section P; Column 3; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENT AND THE VOTERS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: Exit Polls Show Independents, Citing War, Favored Democrats

BYLINE: By JEFF ZELENY and MEGAN THEE

 BODY:
A majority of independent voters aligned with Democratic candidates yesterday, driven by their distress over the Iraq war, disapproval of Congressional leadership and concern about the direction President Bush was leading America, according to interviews with voters as they left their polling places.
 In a contentious midterm election in which both parties forcefully mobilized their bases, voters in the center of the electorate aided Democrats in their quest to overtake Republican majorities in the House and Senate. 
The economy, corruption, terrorism and Iraq, according to the exit polls, were extremely important factors in the minds of about 4 in 10 voters. At the same time, 3 in 10 voters said values and immigration had been extremely important topics.
 Almost 6 in 10 voters disapproved of the war in Iraq, according to the exit polls, and about the same number said they believed the United States should withdraw some, or all, of its troops. Six in 10 voters also said the war had not improved the long-term security of the United States, while one-third of voters said it had.
 The surveys were conducted nationwide by Edison Media Research and Mitofsky International for the National Election Pool, a consortium of television networks and The Associated Press.
 Though Mr. Bush was a central character in the campaign, particularly in the Democrats' television advertisements and talking points, only about 4 in 10 said they cast their votes as a specific show of opposition to the president. About the same number of voters said Mr. Bush had not played a part in their decision, while about one in five voters said they viewed their ballot as a way to support the White House. 
 Still, the president's sagging popularity provided an unavoidable theme for the campaign, and about 6 in 10 voters said they disapproved of how Mr. Bush was handling his job. A majority of voters declared that the nation was seriously on the wrong track, according to the exit polls, and about half of voters said the state of the economy was bad. Of those who were troubled by the economy, 8 in 10 voted for the Democratic candidate.
 While white voters split their support between the main parties, according to the exit polls, a strong majority of black and Hispanic voters picked the Democratic candidate. 
 A majority of voters said they were more concerned with national issues than local ones, which was precisely the sentiment Republicans had worked to avoid as they tried to keep the fight for control of Congress as a series of individual elections rather than a national campaign. 
 The race for the Senate turned on the results in a few states, including Missouri, where 3 in 10 white evangelical voters said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's job performance. 
 Over all, though, white evangelicals were twice as likely as all other voters to voice their approval for the president. On the war, about two-thirds of evangelicals said they approved of Mr. Bush's course, while about two-thirds of all other voters said they disapproved. 
 While the tug of war between the parties went down to the final moments yesterday, with a barrage of television commercials and telephone calls in competitive districts across the country, nearly three-quarters of voters said they had made up their minds last month or earlier. About one-quarter said they had decided within the past week. 
 Even though there were sporadic concerns about the integrity of the election yesterday, nearly 9 in 10 voters said they were confident that their votes would be counted. 
 About 6 in 10 voters said they disapproved of how Congress was handling its job, with fewer than 4 in 10 voicing approval. The findings were potentially perilous for Republican incumbents, particularly in the House, where Democrats believed they could make their strongest showing. 
 It was the mood of the independent voters, though, that provided the biggest dose of optimism for Democrats, with about 6 in 10 supporting the Democratic candidate. While one-third of independents said they were satisfied or enthusiastic about Republican leaders, two-thirds said they were dissatisfied or angry. 
 While economic issues were often overshadowed in the campaign, about half of the voters surveyed said they had just enough money to maintain their standard of living. One-third of voters said they were getting ahead financially, and nearly 2 in 10 said they were falling behind. 
 Six in 10 voters said illegal immigration was of great importance to how they cast their votes. But nearly as many voters said that most illegal immigrants working in the United States should be offered an opportunity to apply for legal status. About 4 in 10 voters said illegal immigrants should be deported.
 In other questions asked of voters, a majority -- nearly 6 in 10 -- rated values issues like same-sex marriage and abortion as important.

Conducting the Polls
 The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left polling places throughout the country.
 The polls were conducted by Edison Media Research of Somerville, N.J., and Mitofsky International of New York City for the National Election Pool, a consortium of ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News.
 The national results are based on 12, 878 voters in 249 precincts across the United States. These include 1,490 absentee voters and early voters interviewed by telephone.
 The state results are based on 1,151 to 2,805 voters in 25 to 50 randomly selected precincts across each of 13 states analyzed by The New York Times. In certain states some interviews were also conducted by phone with absentee voters and early voters.
 In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by no more than plus or minus one to two percentage points nationally, and three to four points in each state, from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters who cast ballots in each of these elections.
 Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, like the reluctance of some voters to take time to fill out the questionnaire, may introduce other sources of error into a poll.
 Prof. Helmut Norpoth of the State University of New York at Stony Brook and Dr. Michael R. Kagay, of Princeton, N.J., assisted The Times in its polling analysis.

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 1802 words

HEADLINE: Northeast

BYLINE: Vikas Bajaj, Julie Bosman, Sewell Chan, Sam Dillon, David M. Herszenhorn, Andy Newman, Robert Pear, Richard Perez-Pena, Ray Rivera and Fernanda Santos contributed to this report.

 BODY:

A Democratic wave sweeps west from Rhode Island, with some landslides along the way.

CONNECTICUT
 Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who ran as an independent after losing badly in the Democratic primary to Ned Lamont, a former town selectman in Greenwich, roared back to defeat Mr. Lamont with heavy support among Republican voters. The Republican candidate, former State Representative Alan Schlesinger, was never a serious contender. 
 Mr. Lamont, who financed his own campaign, ran on a strong antiwar message. Mr. Lieberman, who ran unsuccessfully for president in 2004 and was the Democratic vice presidential nominee in 2000, was mostly spurned by Democrats. But enough Republicans and independents sought out his name at the bottom of the ballot to lift him to a fourth term.
In a stunning pickup for the Democrats, State Senator Chris Murphy ousted Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a 12-term incumbent Republican. Two of the country's most fiercely contested Congressional races remained undecided past 2 a.m. as the Republican incumbents, Christopher Shays and Rob Simmons, faced stiff challenges. 
 Gov. M. Jodi Rell, the Republican who succeeded Gov. John G. Rowland in 2004 after he was implicated in a corruption scandal, won easily.

DELAWARE
 Senator Thomas R. Carper, a Democrat who is a former governor and congressman, easily won re-election, defeating the Republican, Jan C. Ting, a Temple University law professor, by 42 percentage points. 
 In the race for attorney general, Joseph R. Biden III, a Democrat and the son of Delaware's senior senator, beat his Republican challenger, Ferris Wharton, by 13,000 votes.

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
 Adrian M. Fenty, 35, became Washington's youngest mayor in a largely ornamental race after he won the Democratic primary in September. Some 75 percent of voters are Democrats. Mr. Fenty, a two-term city councilman, ran a campaign notable for breaking through racial and economic divides, becoming the first candidate to sweep all eight of the city's voting districts in the primary. The city's delegate to Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, won a ninth term unopposed.

MAINE
 Senator Olympia J. Snowe, a centrist Republican, easily won a third term in the Senate, defeating her Democratic opponent, Jean Hay Bright. Ms. Bright had denounced Ms. Snowe's original vote to authorize the war in Iraq. But in recent weeks, Ms. Snowe criticized the administration's strategy there and said her views reflected the ''independent spirit'' of Maine. 
 The state's two Democratic House members, Representatives Tom Allen and Michael H. Michaud, easily won re-election. Gov. John Baldacci, a Democrat, defeated his Republican challenger, State Senator Chandler Woodcock, who emphasized the state's economic troubles and criticized management of a new health program for the uninsured.

MARYLAND
 Lt. Gov. Michael S. Steele, a Republican, lost to Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, a Democrat, in a closely watched campaign to succeed Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Democrat who is retiring after 30 years. 
 Mr. Steele, who is black, had some success courting black Democratic voters, running an image-based campaign depicting himself as not beholden to either party. But Mr. Cardin likened Mr. Steele to President Bush and took steady aim at his opposition to abortion and embryonic stem cell research, and to his support of the president's handling of the war in Iraq. 
 Democrats also regained the governor's mansion, with Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore narrowly defeating Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., who four years ago was the first Republican elected governor since 1966. In the House, Democrats kept their six-to-two majority, with incumbents winning across the board and John P. Sarbanes, a Democrat and the son of Senator Sarbanes, picking up Mr. Cardin's vacated seat.

MASSACHUSETTS
 Ending 16 years of Republican control of the governor's office, Deval L. Patrick, a former assistant attorney general in the Clinton administration, was elected the Bay State's first black chief executive. He defeated Lt. Gov. Kerry Healey, a Republican, and two others to succeed Gov. Mitt Romney, who is retiring after one term to explore a presidential run in 2008. Heavy turnout was reported. Mr. Patrick, who grew up poor in Chicago, was the Justice Department's top civil rights officer until 1997, and then a corporate lawyer. His campaign focused on education, property taxes and housing. 
 Senator Edward M. Kennedy easily won an eighth term. The state's 10 House incumbents, all Democrats, were re-elected. A ballot measure to allow local authorities to license food stores to sell wine was defeated.

NEW HAMPSHIRE
 House races in the traditional Republican stronghold of New Hampshire emerged as last-minute battlegrounds, with Democrats capturing both seats from incumbent Republicans. In the First District, Carol Shea-Porter, the Democrat, defeated Jeb Bradley; in the Second District, Paul Hodes, the Democrat, defeated Charles Bass. Polls suggested that voters saw the election as a referendum on the war in Iraq and on President Bush. New Hampshire has grown more liberal as people from the Boston suburbs and high-technology companies have migrated north.
 Gov. John Lynch, a Democrat, easily won re-election. 

NEW JERSEY
 In one of this year's most closely watched races, Senator Robert Menendez and his Republican opponent, Thomas H. Kean Jr., waged a down-and-dirty battle, peppered with accusations of corruption and other personal attacks. In the end, Mr. Menendez, a seven-term congressman appointed to the Senate in December by Gov. Jon S. Corzine, wound up the winner, beating Mr. Kean by a narrow margin. 
 Retaining Mr. Menendez's seat was regarded as a major coup for the Democrats, who were locked in a spirited fight to gain control of the Senate. Mr. Menendez drew most of his support from voters who opposed President Bush. Nearly half the voters interviewed as they left the polls rated the war in Iraq and corruption in government as ''extremely important'' in determining their vote.
 Of the state's 11 House races, 10 went to the incumbent. In the other race, Albio Sires, a Democrat, was elected to the 13th District seat vacated by Mr. Menendez for the remaining two months of his term, as well as a subsequent two-year term.

NEW YORK
 The headliners did not supply the drama in this show. Eliot Spitzer was elected governor by a record margin, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton cruised to re-election.
 Surveys of voters leaving the polls showed that both fared especially well among people who oppose the war in Iraq. And after a decade of inroads by Gov. George E. Pataki, who is leaving office, surveys showed Democrats reasserting their traditional dominance among Hispanics, Jews and union members. 
 Andrew M. Cuomo easily defeated Jeanine F. Pirro in the race to replace Mr. Spitzer as attorney general, and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi was re-elected by a wide margin, giving Democrats all the statewide offices for the first time since 1942.
 Democrats captured three Republican-held Congressional seats, and three Republican incumbents narrowly won in normally safe districts, as their party felt the backlash over the war in Iraq and assorted scandals. Michael Arcuri, a Democrat, won the seat of Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert, who is retiring, and two Democrats, Kirsten Gillibrand and John Hall, unseated Representatives John E. Sweeney and Sue W. Kelly. 

PENNSYLVANIA
 Senator Rick Santorum, a staunch conservative who held the No. 3 position in the Senate Republican leadership, lost to Bob Casey, the state treasurer nominated by the Democrats. Exit polls showed a clear split on Iraq. Of those who said they disapproved of the war, 86 percent reported voting for Mr. Casey, while 14 percent voted for Mr. Santorum, according to a poll conducted for The Associated Press and TV networks.
 Gov. Edward G. Rendell, a Democrat seeking a second term, easily defeated his Republican challenger, Lynn Swann, a former football star with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
 Democrats defeated several incumbent House Republicans. In the Seventh District, Joe Sestak, a retired vice admiral, unseated Representative Curt Weldon, a 10-term veteran. Federal agents are investigating whether Mr. Weldon used his influence to help his daughter, a registered lobbyist, win consulting contracts. In the 10th District, Christopher Carney, a Democrat, defeated Representative Don Sherwood, a Republican who apologized to voters for having an extramarital affair with a Peruvian immigrant less than half his age. Representative Melissa A. Hart, a Republican, lost to Jason Altmire, a Democrat, in the Fourth District.

RHODE ISLAND
 Senator Lincoln Chafee, the most liberal Republican in the Senate, opposed the war in Iraq. Rhode Island voters admired him -- 62 percent of them told exit pollsters that they approved of his job performance.
 But 63 percent of voters told exit pollsters they wanted the Senate to change hands, and that was enough to get Mr. Chafee tossed out in favor of Sheldon Whitehouse, a Democrat and former attorney general. 
 Because Mr. Chafee and Mr. Whitehouse agreed on major issues like tax cuts, abortion and gun control, Mr. Whitehouse's campaign focused largely on Mr. Chafee's party affiliation.
 Mr. Whitehouse also benefited from a bruising Republican primary in September that left Mr. Chafee's war chest depleted. Going into the home stretch, Mr. Whitehouse and his Democratic allies outspent Mr. Chafee on television advertisements by more than $1 million.
 Rhode Islanders re-elected their two Democratic congressmen and Gov. Donald L. Carcieri, a Republican. They also voted to allow the Narragansett Indian tribe to open a casino. 

VERMONT
 In Vermont's only House race, State Senator Peter Welch, a Democrat, defeated Martha T. Rainville, a Republican who is adjutant general of the Vermont National Guard. 
 In the race to succeed Senator James M. Jeffords, the retiring independent, Representative Bernard Sanders, an independent who votes with the Democrats, defeated Richard Tarrant, a Republican businessman. The victory by Mr. Sanders became an immediate bit of political trivia: he will be the third sitting senator, along with Charles E. Schumer of New York and Norm Coleman of Minnesota, to be a graduate of James Madison High School in Brooklyn. 
 Gov. James Douglas, a Republican, easily won re-election.

WEST VIRGINIA
 Senator Robert C. Byrd, first elected to the House in 1952 and to the Senate in 1958, is the longest-serving senator in United States history and a few years shy of having the longest Congressional tenure. He easily won a ninth term, defeating John R. Raese, a businessman and former state Republican chairman. All three House incumbents, two Democrats and one Republican, were re-elected.


CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 2006

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies yesterday on the State by State pages about a proposal on the Rhode Island ballot to amend the state Constitution to allow the Narragansett Indian tribe to open a casino in West Warwick misstated the result. Voters there rejected the proposal; they did not approve it.

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; ECONOMIX; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: Election's Over. Now to Tackle The Realities.

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT. 
Email: leonhardt@nytimes.com

 BODY:
For everyone who is worried about the country's big economic problems -- energy policy, health care, the budget deficit -- today is a good day.
 It should be a good day regardless of whether you're elated or disappointed by last night's results, because a campaign that included almost no serious discussion of these issues has now ended. Today marks the start of the 2008 presidential race.
Unlike midterm elections, presidential races tend to revolve largely around economic plans, be it Bill Clinton's 1992 promises to the ''forgotten middle class'' or George W. Bush's vow in 2000 to cut taxes. As Gene Sperling, a former Clinton adviser, says, ''In presidential campaigns, there is a premium on new ideas.'' 
 We could use some fresh economic ideas right now. An honest accounting of the budget deficit would show it to be even larger than the government says it is. High oil prices have helped finance extremist governments across the Middle East, while the five warmest years on record have all occurred in the last decade. Health care costs, like the numbers of the uninsured, keep rising. Wages for most Americans have failed to keep pace with inflation over the last five years. 
 In some cases, the outlines of a potential -- even bipartisan -- solution have already begun to take shape outside of Washington. In other cases, the two parties each have a chance to claim a big issue as their own. With an eye toward Nov. 4, 2008, here is a breakdown of the four biggest:

THE DEFICIT -- When the latest budget numbers came out this summer and they showed a drop in the estimated deficit, I called some former Bush aides -- Glenn Hubbard, Greg Mankiw, Doug Holtz-Eakin, Andrew Samwick -- to give them a chance to gloat. But not one of them was in the mood.
 They all said that the decline was obscuring a much bigger problem: the enormous long-term deficit caused by future Social Security and Medicare payments. ''The real big problem is a decades-long generational issue,'' Mr. Mankiw said. ''That basic challenge often gets forgotten when the short-term situation is getting better.''
 Fortunately, imagining a bipartisan agreement on Social Security isn't all that difficult. Small groups of economists from both parties, including Mr. Samwick, have already negotiated some hypothetical deals. 
 Republicans might compromise by agreeing to increase the amount of income that is subject to the payroll tax -- now $94,200 -- and by cutting benefits for high earners. ''We have a problem,'' Mr. Hubbard says, ''and the most well-off among us ought to bear the biggest burden.'' 
 Democrats could then clear the way for an expansion of personal retirement accounts. Even people who hated Mr. Bush's failed plan for personal accounts should be able to agree that more individual savings would be a good thing.

HEALTH CARE -- There are two main problems with American health care today, and they tend to get confused. The first is that far too many people don't have health insurance. If you are not insured through your job, buying a policy is incredibly expensive, because insurers know that the people in the market for a policy are the ones who expect to get sick.
 A few states -- like Arkansas, Massachusetts and New Mexico, all with ambitious governors -- are trying to address this problem by pooling together their uninsured residents into one buying group, much as a company spreads its medical costs across sick and healthy workers. It's a great idea.
 But it won't solve the second problem: soaring health care costs, which are a much larger part of the long-term deficit than Social Security. Reining in these costs will require cutting back on expensive drugs and procedures that haven't been proved to make a real difference. This issue is about the toughest one around, and I would be surprised if its political moment had yet arrived. We'll probably have to wait for health care spending to go even higher.

GLOBAL WARMING -- Two weeks ago, Sir Nicholas Stern, a top economics official in the British government, released a report that should change the debate over climate change. Sir Nicholas and his staff concluded that without sharp reductions in greenhouse gases, global warming -- and the droughts, hurricanes and floods that it brings -- will probably reduce the world's economic output by at least 5 percent a year. ''The benefits of strong and early action far outweigh the economic costs of not acting,'' the Stern report stated.
 In this country, neither political party is serious about the problem. Instead, both have trotted out laundry lists of futuristic alternative-energy programs. No one can know which ones will actually work, and the planet will keep getting hotter in the meantime. 
 There are only two ways to slow global warming. One is to raise the cost of putting carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, through an energy tax. From Alan Greenspan and Mr. Mankiw on the right to Al Gore and Larry Summers on the left, there is enormous support for this idea, which would do far more to spur research than the current hodgepodge of alternative-energy tax credits.
 That said, none of the big advocates of an energy tax are running for office right now. The second idea -- less efficient but perhaps more politically palatable -- relies on regulations like higher mileage standards for vehicles and limits on carbon use by companies. Senator John McCain says he favors such caps. I suspect we'll hear more from him in the next couple of years. 

LIVING STANDARDS -- Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, recently noted that sweeping economic changes threatened the livelihoods of many workers, and he warned that rising inequality could set off a political reaction. Henry M. Paulson Jr., Mr. Bush's Treasury secretary, said that ''many Americans simply aren't feeling the benefits'' of the current expansion. Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader in the House, puts it this way, ''For the first time in generations, parents worry that their children will not be better off than they are.''
 So where are the bold new solutions? 
 Republicans like to talk about education, skipping over the question of how better schools could help struggling workers in their 40s and 50s. Democrats have become fond of trade barriers, which don't exactly have a good record of lifting a country's living standards. 
 I'm not suggesting the answers are easy. But if we can agree that globalization and technological innovation have made the country richer -- and they have, enormously -- then we should be able to talk about how the winners can do a better job of compensating the losers.
 An immigration policy that lets in fewer low-wage workers, but more doctors and scientists, might be a start, notes Benjamin M. Friedman, the author of ''The Moral Consequences of Economic Growth.'' So might tax cuts for the middle class -- paid for by tax increases on the well-off, who have done very nicely of late.
 There will, inevitably, be huge fights over the solution to any one of these issues. At times, the fights will get nasty, and people will come forward to decry the lack of civility in American politics. So be it. Economies, like democracies, can thrive without civility. They don't thrive if they try to ignore their biggest problems forever.

PUB-DATE: November 8, 2006
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 4; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 1799 words

HEADLINE: South

BYLINE: Vikas Bajaj, Julie Bosman, Sewell Chan, Sam Dillon, David M. Herszenhorn, Andy Newman, Robert Pear, Richard Perez-Pena, Ray Rivera and Fernanda Santos contributed to this report.

 BODY:

In a Republican stronghold, two close Senate races were crucial to the party's success.

ALABAMA
 Considered vulnerable early this year, Gov. Bob Riley, a Republican, made a remarkable comeback and won re-election over Lt. Gov. Lucy Baxley. Mr. Riley had angered conservatives with a proposed tax increase that voters rejected, and Democrats noted his peripheral connections to Washington's lobbying scandals. But he won credit for his handling of the economy and Hurricane Katrina. Five of the seven contested House districts were considered safe for Republicans.

ARKANSAS
 In the race for governor, State Attorney General Mike Beebe, a Democrat, defeated former Representative Asa Hutchinson, a Republican and a former under secretary in the Homeland Security Department. Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, was barred by term limits from running again after a 10-year tenure.
Arkansas had not had an open race for governor since 1978, and the contest generated record spending and a parade of appearances by heavyweights including President Bush and former President Bill Clinton. In House races, none of the four incumbents, three Democrats and a Republican, faced a close challenge. 
 Voters approved a measure to allow bingo and raffles by charitable groups; Arkansas was one of only four states where that type of gambling was illegal.

FLORIDA
 Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat, overwhelmed his Republican challenger, Katherine Harris, the former secretary of state best known for her oversight of the presidential recount of 2000, who ran an erratic campaign. In the battle to succeed Gov. Jeb Bush, who had high approval ratings but was unable to run because of term limits, State Attorney General Charlie Crist, a Republican, easily defeated United States Representative Jim Davis, a Democrat. On the eve of the vote, Mr. Crist declined to appear with President Bush, who flew to Florida to campaign for Republicans.
 Capitalizing on voter discontent with the war in Iraq and the Congressional page scandal that forced the resignation of Representative Mark Foley, Democrats increased their share of Florida's 25 Congressional seats to 9 from 7. One victory came in the race to succeed Mr. Foley, whose name remained on the ballot; the Democratic candidate, Tim Mahoney, a rancher and political newcomer, defeated State Representative Joe Negron, a Republican, who adopted as his campaign slogan ''Punch Foley for Negron.'' 
 In the district that includes Fort Lauderdale, State Senator Ron Klein defeated Representative Clay Shaw, the Republican incumbent. 

GEORGIA
 Georgia, where President Bush campaigned repeatedly in recent weeks, appeared likely to become more Republican than ever. Gov. Sonny Perdue, Republican, overwhelmed his Democratic opponent, Lt. Gov. Mark Taylor. Only 2 of 13 House races appeared competitive, and both were in districts where the president campaigned against incumbent Democrats : Representative Jim Marshall faced a credible challenge from Mac Collins, a Republican former congressman; and Representative John Barrow was battling another former congressman, Max Burns. 

KENTUCKY
 A majority of voters in Kentucky are Democrats, but going into this election, Democrats held only one of the state's six Congressional seats. This year they increased their share to two. In the district that includes Louisville, Democrats had long sought to dislodge Representative Anne M. Northup, a Republican who sits on the House Appropriations Committee. John Yarmuth, a Democratic businessman who once edited an alternative newspaper, defeated Ms. Northup, winning 51 percent of the vote to her 48 percent. 

LOUISIANA
 A 13-way bipartisan brawl for the seat of Representative William J. Jefferson, a Democrat from New Orleans suspected of taking bribes, will require a runoff in December to decide. But the seat will remain Democratic: the two front-runners are Mr. Jefferson, a suave eight-term incumbent, and Karen R. Carter, a state representative who received the state Democratic Party endorsement. 
 Despite being accused by the F.B.I. of stashing $90,000 from a technology company in his freezer, Mr. Jefferson had drawn 29 percent of the votes with 73 percent of precincts reporting. Ms. Carter had collected 25 percent. Louisiana requires a runoff if no candidate gets more than half the votes. The state's six other congressmen -- five Republicans and a Democrat -- were all re-elected.

MISSISSIPPI
 Four years ago, Trent Lott resigned as Senate majority leader after making what many felt were racially insensitive remarks by praising the late Strom Thurmond and his segregationist presidential campaign of 1948. His political influence has not waned at home, though, and Mr. Lott, a Republican, comfortably secured his re-election.
 Mr. Lott, who has represented Mississippi in Washington since 1973, raised and spent $3 million on a race against two cash-strapped opponents: State Representative Erik Fleming, a Democrat, and Harold M. Taylor, a Libertarian and construction worker.
 Recovery from Hurricane Katrina was a top issue, and Mr. Lott heavily promoted his role in helping to pass a huge aid bill for the state's rebuilding projects. In interviews, he said he was weighing a return to leadership if Republicans retained their Senate majority. 

NORTH CAROLINA
 Heath Shuler, a Democratic businessman and former National Football League quarterback, defeated the eight-term Republican incumbent, Charles H. Taylor, for the House seat in the 11th District, in western North Carolina. 
 Before the election, Republicans held a seven-to-six advantage over Democrats in the state's Congressional delegation, but Mr. Shuler's victory tipped that balance. It also helped the Democratic Party's bid to win overall control of the House. 
 A political novice, Mr. Shuler pushed a conservative platform in an area where registered Democrats are in the majority but Republicans usually win national races. Like Mr. Taylor, he opposed abortion and amnesty for illegal immigrants, and supported the right to carry guns.
 In another closely watched race, Michael B. Nifong, the Democratic prosecutor in the Duke University rape case, was re-elected to the Durham County district attorney post. 

OKLAHOMA
 Voters closed a loophole in the state Constitution allowing legislators to be paid even if they are jailed. They also lifted a ban on Election Day alcohol sales that had been on the books since statehood. 
 Gov. Brad Henry, a Democrat, easily won a second term, defeating Representative Ernest Istook, who served seven terms in Congress. Lt. Gov. Mary Fallin, a Republican, won Mr. Istook's seat. Ms. Fallin will become the state's second woman to serve in Congress and the first since 1923.

SOUTH CAROLINA
 Voters approved a constitutional amendment barring legal recognition of same-sex unions and re-elected the Republican governor.
 The amendment prohibits the state from conferring any domestic-partner benefits or recognizing marriages or civil unions from other states. South Carolina is one of eight states voting on such proposals this year. 
 Gov. Mark Sanford defeated State Senator Tommy Moore, a Democrat endorsed by some prominent Republicans. 
 Troubles with electronic voting machines resulted in long lines. Mr. Sanford was initially turned away by poll workers because he did not have a voter registration card.

TENNESSEE
 In one of the nation's most bitterly fought Senate races, Bob Corker, a Republican, narrowly defeated Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., a Democrat from Memphis. 
 Exit polls showed Mr. Corker drawing strong support from white evangelical Christians, who comprised about half of the electorate. Mr. Corker will succeed Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, who is retiring after two terms and weighing a presidential run.
 Mr. Corker, a businessman, was state finance commissioner from 1995 to 1997 and mayor of Chattanooga from 2001 to 2005. 
 Mr. Ford, a five-term congressman, was trying to become the first black senator from the South since Reconstruction. 
 Gov. Phil Bredesen, a Democrat, easily won a second term, defeating State Senator Jim Bryson.
 In the House races, David Davis was elected to succeed Representative Bill Jenkins, a fellow Republican, who is retiring. In the race to succeed Mr. Ford, State Senator Stephen I. Cohen, a Democrat, defeated Mark White, a Republican, and Jake Ford, an independent candidate who is a brother of Mr. Ford. 
 A constitutional ban on same-sex marriage passed overwhelmingly.

TEXAS
 A crowded field in the race for governor helped Rick Perry, a Republican, win re-election without winning a majority of the vote. There is no runoff election in Texas for governor.
 Chris Bell, a Democrat who had to raise fresh campaign funds as recently as late October to keep his ads on radio and TV networks, was expected to finish second. Trailing were Carole Keeton Strayhorn, the state's Republican comptroller, who ran as an independent; Kinky Friedman, the musician who sought to channel Jesse Ventura; and the Libertarian candidate, James Werner.
 Democrats picked up the Congressional seat previously held by Tom DeLay, the former Republican House majority leader who resigned earlier this year but whose name remained on the ballot. With 97 percent of the precincts reporting, Nick Lampson, a Democrat, had 54 percent of the vote to 40 percent for Shelley Sekula-Gibbs, a Republican and Houston City Council member who ran as a write-in candidate. 
 Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Republican, easily won her race.

VIRGINIA
 A razor-thin margin separated the candidates in Virginia's closely watched Senate race. Senator George Allen, a Republican haunted by campaign miscues, traded leads throughout the night with Jim Webb, a Democrat, in a contest that seemed headed for a recount. 
 With nearly 100 percent of precincts reporting but with absentee ballots still being counted, Mr. Webb was leading by two-tenths of a percentage point. More than 130,000 absentee ballots had been requested. Virginia law allows for a state-financed recount if the margin of victory is within one-half of a percentage point. 
 Mr. Allen had been expected to win a second term easily, but after he called a Webb supporter of Indian descent ''macaca'' at an August campaign rally, he was left defending himself against charges of racial insensitivity. 
 Mr. Webb, a Vietnam veteran who was Navy secretary in the Reagan administration, switched parties in opposition to President Bush's handling of the war in Iraq. 
 In House races, incumbent Republicans, Representatives Thelma Drake and Frank R. Wolf, held on in the hotly contested 2nd and 10th Districts, dashing Democratic hopes of picking up vulnerable seats. 
 Voters also passed a state constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage.

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 4; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1711 words

HEADLINE: West 

BYLINE: Vikas Bajaj, Julie Bosman, Sewell Chan, Sam Dillon, David M. Herszenhorn, Andy Newman, Robert Pear, Richard Perez-Pena, Ray Rivera and Fernanda Santos contributed to this report.

 BODY:

Solidly red, or an incursion of blue? The Republicans try to hold onto their turf.

ALASKA
 After beating the Republican incumbent in the primary, Sarah Palin, the mayor of an Anchorage suburb, held a strong lead this morning over a Democratic former governor, Tony Knowles, with half of the votes counted. She hoped to become Alaska's first female governor. Alaska's congressman, Don Young, was re-elected to a 17th term.

ARIZONA
 Immigration was the defining issue in Arizona, where Senator Jon Kyl, the once-untouchable Republican, won a tough re-election campaign against the Democratic challenger, Jim Pederson, a shopping mall developer and former state Democratic Party chairman. With 95 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Kyl had 53 percent of the vote compared with 44 for Mr. Pederson.
Representative J. D. Hayworth, a Republican in a conservative district, lost his fight for a seventh term to Harry Mitchell, also a former state Democratic Party chairman. The seat of Representative Jim Kolbe, a Republican who is retiring, was won by the Democrat, Gabrielle Giffords. Mr. Kolbe refused to endorse the Republican candidate who won the primary. 
 Voters approved a largely symbolic ballot measure to make English the official language of Arizona, though many Hispanic voters opposed the measure. Other initiatives included an increase in the minimum wage, antismoking measures and one to amend the state Constitution to ban same-sex unions. Another initiative would prevent illegal immigrants from participating in certain state-financed programs.
 Gov. Janet Napolitano, a Democrat, defeated her Republican opponent, Len Munsil. 

CALIFORNIA
 A Republican in a Democratic state, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger began the year in trouble after voters rejected his bid to reshape Sacramento with ballot initiatives. But he mended fences with the Legislature, moved to the center, and easily won his first full term.
 Senator Dianne Feinstein was re-elected, and a fellow Democrat, former Gov. Jerry Brown, was leading in early returns for attorney general, hoping to return to statewide office after 24 years.
 In races influenced by the national anti-Republican mood, Republican Representatives Richard Pombo and John Doolittle were in neck-and-neck races for re-election.
 Californians weighed a variety of initiatives, including one to require parental notification before a minor can have an abortion, a $2.60-per-pack increase in cigarette taxes, a lifetime monitoring of sex offenders via a global positioning system and a ban on eminent-domain seizure of private property for private use.

COLORADO
 A strong Democratic showing turned Colorado from red to purple. Democrats elected a governor, expanded their share of Colorado's seven-seat Congressional delegation to at least four from three, and appeared likely to maintain their hold on both houses of the legislature, partial returns indicated. 
 In the race to succeed Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican who is retiring, Bill Ritter, a Democrat and former Denver district attorney who campaigned as a problem-solver, defeated Representative Bob Beauprez, a Republican.
 In the election for the seat Mr. Beauprez vacated in the Denver suburbs, former State Senator Ed Perlmutter, a Democrat, defeated the Republican, Rick O'Donnell, a Republican former chairman of the state's Commission on Higher Education.
 In the Congressional district that represents Colorado's eastern prairie counties and Fort Collins, partial returns showed the Republican, Representative Marilyn Musgrave, in a surprisingly tight contest with the Democrat, State Representative Angie Paccione.
 Even before the vote, some Republicans were blaming not only the war in Iraq but also conservatives in their party for nominating extreme candidates who irritated moderates.

HAWAII
 Senator Daniel K. Akaka, a Democrat, appeared headed for an easy victory over his Republican challenger, State Representative Cynthia Thielen, to win his third full term. Gov. Linda Lingle, a Republican, was running for a second term and was expected to withstand a challenge from the Democratic candidate, Randy Iwase, a former state senator.

IDAHO
 This heavily Republican state had two surprisingly close races. A three-term Republican congressman, C. L. Otter, known as Butch, was ahead of a Democratic newspaper publisher, Jerry Brady, with 42 percent of precincts reporting. Gov. James E. Risch -- a Republican who took office in May after his predecessor, Dirk Kempthorne, became the United States interior secretary -- decided not to seek a full term but to instead run for his former job as lieutenant governor. In the western of Idaho's two House districts, which Mr. Otter represents, State Representative Bill Sali, a Republican, had an early lead over Larry Grant, a Democratic lawyer.
 On the ballot were a proposition to limit the use of eminent domain for economic development and a constitutional ban on same-sex marriage.

MONTANA
 The Senate contest here could not have been tighter or the stakes bigger: Jon Tester, a Democrat, was leading Senator Conrad Burns, a Republican seeking his fourth term. With 64 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Tester was ahead, 51 percent of the vote to 47 percent.
 In surveys of voters leaving the polls, 60 percent said they believed Mr. Burns had been in office too long and 55 percent said they disapproved of the way President Bush was handling his job.
 Gov. Brian Schweitzer has used the race to promote a new style of Western Democrat: strong on gun rights and environmental protection, against free trade deals and in favor of the death penalty, lower taxes and abortion rights. The national significance drew recent visits by Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney in support of Mr. Burns.
 Voters approved an increase in the minimum wage to $6.15 and a measure banning certain state officials from becoming lobbyists too soon after leaving their government jobs.

NEVADA
 An accusation of an improper sexual advance helped narrow the gubernatorial race in Nevada, but Jim Gibbons, a Republican congressman from Reno, had enjoyed a sizable lead over Dina Titus, a Democratic state senator, until late last month when a waitress accused him of trying to force himself upon her in a garage.
 With 85 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Gibbons led by 14,000 votes, or a 47-percent-to-45-percent margin.
 Mr. Gibbons has denied the accusation and has said he walked the woman to the garage and steadied her when she stumbled. Footage from security cameras could prove crucial.
 Mr. Gibbons and Ms. Titus, a political science professor, competed to replace Gov. Kenny Guinn, a popular Republican who cannot run again because of term limits.
 In the Senate race, John Ensign, a Republican, was on track to soundly beat Jack Carter, a Democrat and son of former President Jimmy Carter.
 Nevadans also rejected a proposal that would have legalized marijuana. A separate proposal banning smoking in public places was too close to call. 

NEW MEXICO
 In a House race where Democrats hoped to wrest a seat from Republicans, the Democratic attorney general, Patricia A. Madrid, led the incumbent, Heather A. Wilson, by less than a percentage point with 59 percent of precincts reporting. 
 Iraq was a hot topic in this campaign to represent a district around Albuquerque that has sent Republicans to the House for nearly 40 years. Ms. Wilson, a former National Security Council staff member, sits on the House Intelligence Committee, and Ms. Madrid has held her partly to blame for inaccurate reports on Iraq's weapons programs.
 New Mexico's Democratic senator, Jeff Bingaman, and Democratic governor, Bill Richardson, won easy re-election, as did the state's other two representatives, a Democrat and a Republican.

OREGON
 Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski, a Democrat, won re-election, overcoming a tough challenge from his Republican opponent, Ron Saxton. 
 Mr. Saxton had cast the race as a referendum on four years of ''lackluster leadership'' by Mr. Kulongoski. He promised new ideas to improve schools and increase the efficiency of state government.
 The state's five House members, four Democrats and one Republican, all won re-election. Representative Darlene Hooley, a five-term Democrat, faced the stiffest challenge, in the Fifth District, from Mike Erickson, a businessman who put more than $1.3 million of his money into the race. Mr. Erickson said he was ''not part of the partisan bickering, not a part of the scandals'' in Washington.
 Voters were also deciding an initiative on parental notification for abortions.

UTAH
 Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the ranking Republican on the Finance and Judiciary Committees, easily won a sixth term, defeating a Democratic opponent, Peter Ashdown, the founder of an Internet service provider. Utah's three House incumbents, two Republicans and one Democrat, were easily re-elected.

WASHINGTON
 Senator Maria Cantwell, a Democrat, defeated her Republican challenger, Michael McGavick, to win her first re-election bid.
 Ms. Cantwell's seat seemed in jeopardy earlier this year, when she faced tough criticism from liberal constituents over her 2002 vote to authorize the use of force in Iraq. She rebounded, though, managing to fend off Mr. McGavick, a business executive, and three left-wing rivals with a solid campaign based on issues like renewable energy and environmental preservation; both are dear to local voters.
 Ms. Cantwell opposed the repeal of the federal estate tax, and a majority of voters agreed with her. With 28 percent of the precincts reporting, it was unclear if the other two other initiatives on the state ballot, which dealt with energy conservation and eminent domain, would be approved. 

WYOMING
 Representative Barbara Cubin won her at-large House seat during Newt Gingrich's ''Republican revolution'' of 1994. But even in conservative Wyoming, Ms. Cubin's sometimes caustic personality turned off some voters and gave Gary Trauner a once unthinkable chance of winning a seat for Democrats in Vice President Dick Cheney's home state. Ms. Cubin was leading Mr. Trauner by about 650 votes with 98 percent counted in a race that was too close to call. Gov. Dave Freudenthal, a Democrat, and Senator Craig Thomas, a Republican, kept their seats.


CORRECTION-DATE: November 22, 2006

 CORRECTION:
Reports about Washington State in the State by State election summary on Nov. 8 and 9 referred incorrectly to a voter initiative on property rights, which was defeated. The measure would make governments pay for enacting zoning restrictions that reduce the value of private land; it would not regulate eminent domain.

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2006 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1773 words

HEADLINE: Midwest

BYLINE: Vikas Bajaj, Julie Bosman, Sewell Chan, Sam Dillon, David M. Herszenhorn, Andy Newman, Robert Pear, Richard Perez-Pena, Ray Rivera and Fernanda Santos contributed to this report.

 BODY:

A big shift in Ohio, and a Senate battle in Missouri that turned all eyes to the Show Me State.

ILLINOIS
 For more than 30 years, the Republican elder statesman Henry J. Hyde held an unbreakable grip on the suburbs west and northwest of Chicago. As he retires, his party will retain control of his Sixth District seat, with State Senator Peter Roskam, a Republican, winning a tight race against Tammy Duckworth, the Democratic candidate. 
 Ms. Duckworth, a former helicopter pilot who lost both her legs while serving in the war in Iraq, had a compelling personal story and fervently attacked President Bush's handling of the war, giving Democrats high hopes of picking up a Republican seat. But Mr. Roskam prevailed, clashing with Ms. Duckworth on abortion rights, embryonic stem cell research and tax cuts. He had to tread carefully in supporting the war without seeming to question Ms. Duckworth's patriotism.
Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, a Democrat, won a second term despite a federal investigation into the state's hiring practices. 

INDIANA
 
 The Republican bloodbath started early in Indiana, which along with Kentucky had the earliest poll closings in the country. In the Eighth Congressional District, nicknamed the ''Bloody Eighth'' because of its history of close races, the outcome was anything but close. Brad Ellsworth, a conservative Democrat, handily defeated John Hostettler, the six-term Republican. Mr. Ellsworth, the sheriff of Vanderburgh County, was one of three Democrats to oust incumbents. 
 In the Second District, Joe Donnelly, a lawyer, defeated Chris Chocola, who had been seeking a third term. In the Ninth District, Baron Hill, a former two-term congressman, took back the seat from Mike Sodrel, who won in 2004. Senator Richard G. Lugar, a Republican, easily won re-election to a sixth term.

IOWA
 Chet Culver, the Democratic candidate for governor, defeated Representative Jim Nussle, a Republican, in the race to succeed Gov. Tom Vilsack, a Democrat. Mr. Culver, the son of former Senator John C. Culver, is the Iowa secretary of state. Mr. Nussle, a member of Congress for 16 years, has cast many votes to cut spending as chairman of the House Budget Committee.
 In a typical attack, Mr. Culver said that President Bush and Mr. Nussle had cut student loans to help pay for ''trillions of dollars in tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans.''
 In the contest for Mr. Nussle's seat in Congress, the Democratic candidate, Bruce L. Braley, a former president of the Iowa Trial Lawyers Association, defeated the Republican, Mike Whalen, who owns and operates hotels and restaurants. Mr. Braley said Congress must ''roll back the Bush tax cut for millionaires.''
 In the Des Moines area, Representative Leonard L. Boswell, a moderate-to-conservative Democrat, won re-election, defeating Jeff Lamberti, a Republican state legislator.

KANSAS
 It can be hard to tell Democrats from Republicans in Kansas, where Democrats have nominated party-switchers for several offices.
 Gov. Kathleen Sebelius, a Democrat, easily won a second term, and for the second time she chose a lieutenant governor candidate who until recently was a Republican.
 Another former Republican, Paul Morrison, a district attorney, defeated Attorney General Phill Kline, who was criticized for using evangelical churches as extensions of his campaign organization.
 Representative Jim Ryun, a Republican, lost to Nancy Boyda in a mostly Republican district.

MICHIGAN
 Voters approved a hotly contested proposition that prohibits public institutions from considering race or sex in public education, employment or contracting. 
 With 75 percent of the precincts reporting, the measure passed with 58 percent of the vote, even though it was opposed by much of the state's political and civic leadership. It was backed by Ward Connerly, a former University of California regent, and a white woman who was denied admission to the University of Michigan. Despite a late spurt of Republican spending in the state, Gov. Jennifer Granholm, a Democrat, won a second term, overcoming a largely self-financed challenge by Dick DeVos, a former president of the Amway Corporation. 
 Senator Debbie Stabenow, a Democrat, defeated Michael Bouchard, a sheriff and a Republican, to win her second term.
 Democrats were hoping to take control of at least one chamber of the Michigan Legislature. Both houses have had Republican majorities since 1999. 
 None of the state's 15 Congressional seats, 9 of which are held by Republicans, were expected to change hands, however.

MINNESOTA
 In one of the most hotly contested governor's races, Gov. Tim Pawlenty, a Republican, battled the Democratic challenger, Mike Hatch, the state attorney general. The campaign season in Minnesota was largely defined by debates on Iraq, immigration and taxes. Mr. Pawlenty, once discussed as a possible vice presidential candidate, found himself in an unexpectedly difficult race; in recent polls he trailed Mr. Hatch by several percentage points. 
 Polls suggested that Minnesota voters were extremely dissatisfied with Congress. Representative Gil Gutknecht, a six-term Republican, was in a close race with the Democratic challenger, Tim Walz, a teacher and former member of the National Guard.
 The seat being vacated by Senator Mark Dayton, a Democrat, was won by another Democrat, Amy Klobuchar, the county attorney in Hennepin County. She defeated Representative Mark Kennedy, the Republican, who was hurt by his defense of President Bush's position on the war.

MISSOURI
 In a crucial Senate victory for Democrats, the state auditor, Claire C. McCaskill, narrowly defeated the Republican incumbent, Jim Talent.
 Ms. McCaskill's margin tracked closely with the vote on a hotly debated ballot measure on stem cell research that she supported and Mr. Talent opposed; it appeared headed for approval. The initiative would block the state legislature from banning any federally allowed stem cell research, including the embryonic cloning opposed by conservative Christians.
 President Bush visited Missouri twice in recent days to support Mr. Talent. But exit polls found that Ms. McCaskill drew 57 percent of the votes of those who decided in the last three days.
 Missourians voted to increase the minimum wage to $6.50 an hour from $5.15, with an annual cost-of-living increase. They also raised cigarette taxes by 80 cents a pack. The state's five Republican and four Democratic House members were all re-elected.

NEBRASKA
 Senator Ben Nelson, a former governor who is one of the most conservative Democrats in the Senate, easily won a second term. 
 The Republican challenger, Pete Ricketts, who was the chief operating officer of Ameritrade, the financial services company, spent millions of dollars of his own money on advertisements. 
 But Mr. Nelson, who had voted for many of President Bush's tax cuts, had bipartisan appeal in this Republican-leaning state.
 The governor, Dave Heineman, a Republican, also won re-election. He defeated the Democratic challenger, David Hahn, a political newcomer, lawyer and Internet entrepreneur. 
 Scott Kleeb, a Democrat and Yale-educated rancher, won the endorsement of the conservative Omaha World-Herald, the state's largest newspaper, in his bid for an open House seat.

NORTH DAKOTA
 Although this is a heavily Republican state that favored President Bush by 27 percentage points in 2000 and 2004, two Democrats -- Senator Kent Conrad and Representative Earl Pomeroy -- easily defeated their relatively unknown challengers.
 Voters overwhelmingly approved a ballot initiative to curb the government's power to seize private property through eminent domain.
 This has been a hot issue around the country since the Supreme Court last year upheld the government's right to transfer property from one private party to another for the purpose of economic development. 

OHIO
 Republicans' long dominance of Ohio politics came to an end.
 Voters angered by government corruption, factory closings and President Bush's handling of the Iraq war elected Democrats for governor, United States senator and the top state posts of attorney general, secretary of state and treasurer. Democrats also increased their share of Ohio's 18-member delegation in the House of Representatives. Gov. Bob Taft was leaving office disgraced by scandal. The Democratic candidate to succeed him, Representative Ted Strickland, a Methodist minister, crushed the Republican, Secretary of State J. Kenneth Blackwell, a Christian conservative and a leading black politician in the state.
 In the Senate race, Representative Sherrod Brown, a Democrat, unseated Mike DeWine, the incumbent Republican, after attacking him during the campaign for backing President Bush on Iraq and for supporting free trade agreements that now appear to have cost the state jobs.
 Zack Space, a Democratic lawyer, won the Congressional seat held by Representative Bob Ney, who pleaded guilty in October to accepting illegal gifts from lobbyists. Mr. Space defeated State Senator Joy Padgett, the Republican candidate.

SOUTH DAKOTA
 Voters rejected a measure passed by the Legislature that would bar doctors from performing abortions except to prevent the death of pregnant women. The measure had been described as a ''full frontal attack'' on Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion.
 With 70 percent of precincts reporting, 55 percent of the vote was against the measure. In pre-election polls, a majority of voters indicated opposition to it because it did not include exemptions for rape and incest. The measure would have allowed abortions only if necessary to save a woman's life.
 In the major statewide race, Gov. Mike Rounds, a Republican, comfortably won re-election against his Democratic challenger, Jack Billion, a former state representative.

WISCONSIN
 Gov. James E. Doyle, a Democrat seeking his second term, won a close race for governor against Representative Mark Green, the Republican, in a campaign dominated by debates over stem cell research, taxes and the economy. The stem cell issue is strongly felt in Wisconsin, where the first human embryonic stem cells were isolated. Mr. Doyle favors all types of stem cell research, while Mr. Green opposes research on embryonic stem cells.
 Senator Herb Kohl, a Democrat, easily won his fourth term in office.
 Voters considered two ballot initiatives. One asked whether the death penalty, banned in the state since the 1850s, should be reinstated. And voters approved a measure to amend the state Constitution to prohibit same-sex unions; early polls indicated voters had been strongly divided over the issue.

HEADLINE: Democrats Topple G.O.P. Incumbents in Three Senate Contests

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

 BODY:
Democrats defeated Republican senators in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island and held off spirited Republican challenges in New Jersey and Maryland in their bid to win back control of the Senate, which was lost to the Republicans in 2002.
 Democrats turned out the incumbents Rick Santorum in Pennsylvania, Mike DeWine in Ohio and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, all of whom had been struggling against a Democratic tide that built throughout the fall.
 One of the most closely watched races -- and one that could well determine control of the Senate -- was in Virginia, where Senator George Allen, a Republican, was in an excruciatingly close contest with Jim Webb, a Democrat and former secretary of the Navy. The margin was whisker-thin, and the race could be headed for a recount. 
 With votes still being counted, Mr. Webb addressed a cheering crowd after 11 p.m., saying: ''This is a very, very close race. When we look at where the votes are that have yet to be counted, it looks very, very good for our side.''
 ''It's going to take awhile to count all the rest of these votes,'' said Mr. Webb, who said his campaign would be carefully monitoring absentee ballots, which he said seemed to be leaning in his favor.
 The Democrats need to pick up six seats to gain control of the Senate, which Republicans control 55 to 45. If Mr. Webb prevails, the Democrats would win control of the Senate by unseating Republican incumbents in Missouri and Montana, but those races were undecided early this morning.
 In poll after poll in Pennsylvania and Ohio, voters expressed concern about the economy, dismay with corruption scandals involving Republican officials and discontent about the war in Iraq.
 The Senate race in Pennsylvania was the nation's second most expensive, after New York's, with Mr. Santorum spending $23 million trying to fend off a challenge from Bob Casey, a moderate, anti-abortion Democrat who spent $13 million.
 In Ohio, Mr. DeWine lost to Representative Sherrod Brown, a liberal Democrat.
 Ohio was particularly difficult ground for Republicans, who fielded a weak candidate for governor in J. Kenneth Blackwell, the secretary of state. Corruption scandals involving two other Republicans, Gov. Bob Taft and Representative Bob Ney, hurt the party's chances from the top to the bottom of the ballot.
 Sheldon Whitehouse, the Democratic former attorney general of Rhode Island, defeated Mr. Chafee, a liberal Republican who defied President Bush on the Iraq war. But Mr. Chafee could not hold his seat in heavily Democratic Rhode Island in a climate that favored Democrats across the country.
 In New Jersey, Senator Robert Menendez's victory denied Republicans one of their few chances to gain a Senate seat held by Democrats. Mr. Menendez was appointed to the Senate in January when former Senator Jon Corzine became New Jersey's governor.
 Maryland, ordinarily a reliably Democratic state, gave Democrats a scare in recent weeks as the race grew tighter between Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, a Democrat, and Michael Steele, the Republican lieutenant governor.
 Mr. Steele, who is black, won the endorsement of Wayne K. Curry, the influential former Democratic county executive in majority-black Prince George's County. But in the end, Mr. Steele was unable to overcome Maryland's nearly two-to-one Democratic tilt in voter registration.
 Democrats were also expected to benefit from two victories by independents. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut won re-election as an independent after losing a bitter Democratic primary to Ned Lamont, a wealthy antiwar candidate from Greenwich. Another independent, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont, also won election to the Senate. Both are expected to caucus with Democrats.
 Elsewhere, most incumbents coasted to re-election as expected. The Democratic Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Bill Nelson of Florida, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, Debbie Stabenow of Michigan and Thomas R. Carper of Delaware all won.
 Republicans held on to the seats of Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, Trent Lott of Mississippi, Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas and Craig Thomas of Wyoming. 
 Political analysts have been saying for weeks that control of the Senate would come down to races in Missouri, Montana, Tennessee and Virginia, and their predictions appeared to hold as polls closed. 
 Democrats had singled out Republican-held seats in Virginia, Rhode Island, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Missouri, Tennessee and Montana and poured tens of millions of dollars into those races. To win a majority, Democrats also needed to make sure they protected seats in competitive contests in New Jersey, Maryland, Michigan, Minnesota and Washington.
 Other threatened Republican Senate incumbents were Conrad Burns of Montana, a three-term Republican conservative who narrowly won re-election six years ago, and Jim Talent in Missouri, who was running against Claire McCaskill, the state auditor. Mr. Burns faced Jon Tester, State Senate president, third-generation rancher and hunting enthusiast. While Montana supported President Bush in 2000 and 2004, two years ago it elected Brian Schweitzer, a Democrat, as governor. 
 Voters in Virginia were to decide on the political aspirations of Mr. Allen, a Republican who was once considered credible presidential material. But a series of racially insensitive comments and his poor handling of revelations that his mother was Jewish weakened his re-election campaign and may well cripple his political career.
 Mr. Webb, a decorated marine combat veteran and respected novelist, is a former Republican who served as Navy secretary under President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Webb faced criticism for things he wrote more than two decades ago questioning whether women belonged in combat and the military academies.
 One unsuccessful Democratic candidate, Harold E. Ford Jr., had faced an uphill fight in Tennessee. Despite running what political professionals called one of the most skillful campaigns in the country, he lost to Bob Corker, the Republican former mayor of Chattanooga, in the race for the seat vacated by the retirement of Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader.
